headline: Disney Gets In on the Netbook Craze
abstract: Disney’s new netbook offers built-in safety measures for a kid’s Web activity, not to mention an exterior design that would stand out in a conference room.

headline: Debtholders vs. U.S. Over Chrysler Deal
abstract: The Obama administration has entered a tense showdown with several of the nation’s largest banks that appears likely to determine whether Chrysler survives, The New York Times’s Bill Vlasic and David E. Sanger write.

headline: Twitter Trends: Why Do Men Follow Men?
abstract: A study by researchers at Harvard Business School finds some strange gender-related patterns among Twitter users.

headline: Robin Hood Event Adjusts to Tough Times
abstract: By the gilded standards of the hedge fund world, The Robin Hood Foundation’s spring fund-raising event, which has long set the pace for charity benefits, seemed like a lean night out.

headline: Intel Fined Record $1.45 Billion in Antitrust Case
abstract: The European Commission on Wednesday fined Intel a record of about $1.45 billion (1.06 billion euros) for abusing its dominance in the market for computer chips to exclude Advanced Micro Devices, which is Intel’s only serious rival.

headline: Chrysler and Fiat Hope for Happy Relationship
abstract: When Daimler-Benz merged with Chrysler in 1998, their leaders told the world to “expect the extraordinary” from the German-American auto giant.

headline: Hail Our Alma Mater, Dear Old MDCU
abstract: Advertising agencies trying to fill all the vacant jobs in the digital realm sometimes find themselves facing a dilemma: steal people from other agencies or nurture digital talent from scratch. MDC Partners, which owns Crispin Porter & Bogusky and Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners, and dozens of other agencies, is joining with the University of Colorado at Boulder to create a school to be called Boulder Digital Works.

headline: Ratings: Sluggish Debut for ‘The Unusuals’
abstract: ABC’s new police drama “The Unusuals” made a sluggish debut in the ratings on Wednesday, earning just 6.8 million viewers in its 10 p.m. time slot, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: Hummer Buyer Lobbying Regulators, Report Says
abstract: The potential buyer of General Motors’ Hummer division will begin formal talks with Chinese regulators to seek approval for its acquisition, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Universal Express Boss Loses Appeal
abstract: Richard Altomare, the former chief executive of Universal Express, has lost his appeal to the Supreme Court. On Monday, the court turned down his request to hear his case.

headline: Cell Biosciences Raises $10 Million
abstract: Cell Biosciences has secured $10 million in a third round, bringing its total fund raising to date to $50.5 million, VentureBeat reported.

headline: Electronic Patient Records Will Force Consolidation in Health Care
abstract: The plan to accelerate the adoption of electronic patient records will consolidate the health technology industry. Allscripts, Epic and Cerner could well be targets.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp Reports Loss
abstract: Fifth Third Bancorp says it posted a loss in the first quarter including preferred dividends, as rising losses on commercial loans hurt the large Midwest regional bank, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Goodbye to Naked Shorting
abstract: Naked short-selling.

headline: S.E.C. to Foster Challenges in Board Elections
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission will propose new rules on Wednesday that would make it possible for a company’s shareholders to elect a limited number of independent directors, according to commission officials.

headline: March Update from GeoSphere Capital
abstract: GeoSphere Capital Management, a hedge-fund firm run by a former analyst at SAC Capital Advisors, reported modest declines in March but said it was still up for the year.

headline: An Ominous Sign for ‘Sit Down, Shut Up’
abstract: ArtsBeat reports that “Fox has pulled the final episode of its animated series “Sit Down, Shut Up.”

headline: For Some Hedge Funds, 2009 Looks Brighter
abstract: After a bleak 2008, things may be looking up for some hedge funds, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Tech Mahindra Wins Auction For Satyam
abstract: Tech Mahindra, a joint venture between British Telecom and the Indian conglomerate Mahindra & Mahindra, stands to win control of Satyam Computer Services after a bid that values the fraud-damaged company at $1.2 billion.

headline: Tuesday Ratings: NBC’s ‘Talent’ Is the Top Draw
abstract: The fourth season premiere of NBC’s reality competition “America’s Got Talent” attracted 11.3 million viewers, the largest network television audience on Tuesday night, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: Why the Comcast-Time Warner Deal Blasts Open TV
abstract: For people who hope the openness and flexibility of the Internet will come to mainstream television, the deal announced today between Comcast and Time Warner is great news. They just don’t see yet how it blows apart the tight bond between cable content and cable delivery.

headline: Union Assails Citigroup for Planned Pay Raises
abstract: The nation’s largest public employees union is taking aim at Citigroup, saying it is “dismayed” by the bank’s plan to raise salaries for its employees by as much as 50 percent to offset smaller bonuses.

headline: F.T.C. Names New Competition Director
abstract: Richard A. Feinstein of Boies Schiller & Flexner has been chosen as the next director of the Federal Trade Commission’s competition bureau, putting him in a position to help shape the new administration’s stance toward big merger deals.

headline: Q & A: A Picture Mail Workaround for iPhone
abstract: A workaround for iPhone users who want to picture message.

headline: The Challenge of Defusing the Derivatives Time Bomb
abstract: If Wall Street succeeds in preserving the complexity and secrecy in the world of derivatives, it will be the customers, and the financial system, that are at risk, The New York Times’s Floyd Norris writes.

headline: A New Boss for a Channel About Crime and Justice
abstract: Henry Schleiff, a fixture of the New York media scene who ran Court TV for eight years, has joined Discovery Communications as the president of the Investigation Discovery channel.

headline: Hurricane Swine Flu
abstract: As Mexico attempts to jump-start its moribund tourist industry, which has been hit hard by the flu outbreak, some new statistics from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will not help.

headline: A Window Opens for Stock Issues
abstract: The window for companies to sell stock seems to be creaking open, and corporations that need capital should leap through it while they have the chance, Breakingviews says.

headline: Is More Care Better Care?
abstract: An economist responds to criticisms of research showing vast differences between regions in health-care spending and suggesting that higher-spending regions do not get better results.

headline: Hit by Madoff, Swiss Bank Now Seeks Acquisitions
abstract: Union Bancaire Privée, the private Swiss bank hit hard by the Madoff scandal, has several billion Swiss francs available for takeovers and is looking for acquisitions in Switzerland, its chief executive said.

headline: G.M. Bankruptcy: The Swaps Disaster That Wasn’t
abstract: Despite the nightmare scenarios predicted by credit-default swap specialists, General Motors’ default has scarcely stirred the swaps market.

headline: Judge Approves Santander’s Madoff Settlement
abstract: A judge approved a settlement requiring a unit of Banco Santander of Spain, which fed $3 billion to Bernard L. Madoff, to pay $235 million for potential legal claims.

headline: VisaNet Said to Plan $4.5 Billion Brazilian I.P.O.
abstract: Visa’s Brazilian affiliate hopes raise 10 billion reais ($4.5 billion) in an initial public offering in June, Valor Economico reported. The move comes after the unit, known as VisaNet, pulled its I.P.O. plans last year, the newspaper said.

headline: Amid U.S. Inquiry, Pequot Capital Is Shutting Down
abstract: Pequot Capital Management, the $3 billion hedge fund run by the renowned investor Arthur J. Samburg, has decided to close its doors amid an investigation into possible insider trading in Microsoft shares that started in 2001.

headline: Current Media Withdraws I.P.O. Registration
abstract: Current Media, an independent media company that was founded by former Vice President Al Gore and a businessman, Joel Hyatt, has withdrawn its registration to raise as much as $100 million in an initial public offering, citing “market conditions.”

headline: Lions Gate’s Loss Comes In Above Expectations
abstract: Lions Gate Entertainment, under pressure from Carl C. Icahn to improve its balance sheet, said Monday it posted a larger-than-expected loss for its fiscal fourth quarter.

headline: Chief Is Gone, but the Office Bill Remains
abstract: Time Warner‘s former chairman, Richard Parsons, has moved on. But the company still plans to spend $776,000 this year on his office space.

headline: Fed Balance Sheet Expansion: Some Takeaways
abstract: This chart, showing the expansion of the Federal Reserve’s balance sheet, has received a lot of attention lately:

headline: Screen Actors Guild Approves Studio Contract
abstract: The vote ended a nearly yearlong standoff that resulted in the union’s missing out on potential pay increases and on contracts on new television series.

headline: Monday Ratings: Low Ratings for Jackson Commemorations
abstract: Fox’s two-hour encore of last season’s “American Idol” episode featuring songs by Michael Jackson garnered just 4.2 million viewers.

headline: World Leaders Pledge $1.1 Trillion to Tackle Crisis
abstract: Struggling to bridge deep divides over how to revive a paralyzed global economy, the leaders of the world’s largest economies agreed Thursday to bail out developing countries, stimulate world trade and regulate financial firms more stringently.

headline: Start-Up Hitches Ride on I.B.M. With Super-Charged Server
abstract: Founded by former Sun and I.B.M. executives, Schooner thinks it can speed up Internet-centric software jobs through some unique products and a unique business model.

headline: U.S. Reportedly Wants Bank of America and Citi to Add Capital
abstract: Shares of Bank of America and Citigroup fell in European trading Tuesday, as investors reacted to a report in The Wall Street Journal that United States regulators have told the banks that they may need to raise more capital following the government’s stress tests.

headline: Ex-Host of CNBC’s ‘Fast Money’ Moves to MSNBC
abstract: Dylan Ratigan, the former host of CNBC’s “Fast Money,” will move to a different neighborhood within NBC’s cable properties, with a new assignment as the anchor of a two-hour discussion program on MSNBC.

headline: Q & A Friday Tip of the Week: Setting the Tivo Remotely
abstract: New ways to set your Tivo when you’re not at home.

headline: S.E.C. Said to Plan Stop of Broker Voting
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission plans to stop letting brokers vote on behalf of their clients, a move that would likely aid activist investors in proxy contests, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Buyout Firms Win BankUnited Auction
abstract: BankUnited FSB, the biggest independent bank in Florida, was seized and sold to a consortium of private equity firms on Thursday in the largest bank failure this year.

headline: House Panel Subpoenas Fed Records on Merrill Deal
abstract: Leaders of a House committee said Tuesday that they had subpoenaed the Federal Reserve to hand over e-mails, notes and other documents related to its role in Bank of America‘s acquisition of Merrill Lynch.

headline: Oscar’s New Math Causes High Anxiety
abstract: Academy’s decision to count to ten with best picture has the Oscar ninny kingdom in a tizzy.

headline: Throwing the Board Out With the Light Bulb
abstract: When one part of an LED lamp fails, right now you have to throw out the whole unit.

headline: KKR Postpones Big Board Debut
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the giant private equity firm, said it was officially postponing a listing on the New York Stock Exchange, instead seeking to revise a merger with an affiliate that would give it an Amsterdam listing.

headline: Visual Diary: Shades and Guns
abstract: These three men don’t have much in common, but they do fight on the same side in this war. For now.

headline: Duke Energy Keeps Eye Peeled for Distressed Wind Assets
abstract: Duke Energy is on the lookout for certain distressed wind energy assets, executives said in a conference call Tuesday held to discuss its earnings for the first quarter of 2009.

headline: EBay to Buy South Korea’s Gmarket For $1.2 Billion
abstract: EBay offered to buy a South Korean online retailer, Gmarket, for up to $1.2 billion, a deal that would make it the leader in the world’s sixth-largest e-commerce market.

headline: Bank Analyst Sees Depression-Size Loan Losses
abstract: Michael Mayo, the prominent bank analyst who recently left Deutsche Bank to join a unit of Calyon, initiated coverage of 11 large banks in the United States, assigning all of them “underperform” or “sell” ratings.

headline: Internet Star @ Least 473 Years Old
abstract: Despite not having an e-mail address or a Twitter account, a Florentine merchant named Francesco Lapi used the symbol @ in a letter written 473 years ago, on May 4, 1536.

headline: The Life and/or Death of the Euro
abstract: The financial crisis has highlighted a paradox of the euro: a bunch of countries want in, while — arguably — some might benefit from getting out.

headline: Magna Chief Expects to Complete Opel Deal Soon
abstract: Siegfried Wolf, head of Magna International, said he expected to take over Opel by the end of September.

headline: Analysts See Weak Spots in Goldman’s Results
abstract: At first glance, Goldman Sachs seems to have had a blowout first quarter. But some Wall Street analysts don’t think the results are as amazing as they initially appeared.

headline: G.M. Files for Bankruptcy Protection
abstract: General Motors filed for bankruptcy protection in federal court in Manhattan on Monday, a humbling fate for the longtime titan of American industry.

headline: Another View: How to Save General Motors
abstract: J. Ronald Trost and Josiah M. Daniel III, two leading specialists in bankruptcy law, offer some further thoughts on how to revive General Motors through an expedited bankruptcy reorganization:

headline: PBS Brings Bugs, Presidents and Soufflés to the Web
abstract: A new portal from PBS offers full episodes of many shows on public TV.

headline: Ratings: First Place for the Final 5 Idols
abstract: As the final five contestants on “American Idol” competed for a chance at the top prize on Tuesday, Fox once again took first place in the night’s ratings.

headline: Florida Fund Backs One of Ackman’s Target Nominees
abstract: The Florida State Board of Administration, which oversees $115 billion in pension fund assets, has voted to support one of William A. Ackman’s nominees for the board of the giant retailer Target.

headline: Guilty Plea for Tax Shelter Fraud in BDO Seidman Case
abstract: A former vice chairman of the accounting firm BDO Seidman pleaded guilty to charges that he had helped clients evade more than $200 million in taxes.

headline: AT&T Doesn’t Want to Follow You (Except When It Does)
abstract: AT&T testified in Congress about high standards needed before it tracks the online behavior of customers. But the company already follows users on its own site.

headline: Ex-Merrill Lynch Executives in Enron Case Can Be Retried
abstract: An appeals court said the retrial of three former Merrill Lynch executives connected to an Enron deal would not violate their constitutional protections against double jeopardy.

abstract: Questions have arisen about the fund business of private-equity financier Danny Pang, including allegations by a former executive of his $4 billion Private Equity Management Group that part of the enterprise involves a Ponzi scheme, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Much Vilified, Financial Titans Find a Friend in Bloomberg
abstract: Gov. Jon S. Corzine is suing Lehman Brothers, saying the firm shortchanged New Jersey’s pension funds. Most members of New York’s Congressional delegation pushed for a 90 percent tax on American International Group bonuses. Politicians in Albany and beyond have pushed through income tax increases on the wealthy.

headline: Chrysler Holdout Investors Must Name Themselves
abstract: The judge overseeing Chrysler‘s bankruptcy case in Manhattan ruled Tuesday afternoon that the group of dissident secured debtholders in the case must make their identities public, ruling against their effort to submit their roster under seal.

abstract: The potential buyer of General Motors’ Hummer division will begin formal talks with Chinese regulators to seek approval for its acquisition, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Universal Express Boss Loses Appeal
abstract: Richard Altomare, the former chief executive of Universal Express, has lost his appeal to the Supreme Court. On Monday, the court turned down his request to hear his case.

headline: Lehman Questioned Over Securities Sales, Report Says
abstract: Regulators have questioned former Lehman Brothers executives over their marketing of auction-rate securities, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Battle for Control of Children’s Place Heats Up
abstract: A schoolyard skirmish that started nearly two years ago between The Children’s Place and its former chief executive, Ezra Dabah, is heating up ahead of a crucial shareholder vote next month for control of the clothing retailer.

headline: Debt Fear Eases, and Shares Take a Ride
abstract: Wall Street jitters about waning demand for government debt eased a bit Thursday, and stocks were sharply higher.

headline: Renault Joins Ferrari and the Others in Threat to Leave F1
abstract: The Renault team today announced that it too will leave Formula One at the end of the 2009 season if the International Automobile Federation leaves its new two-tier rules system in place. Yesterday Ferrari announced it would leave if the rules did not change, and over the weekend in Barcelona, Toyota and the Red Bull teams also said they would leave.

headline: Weekend Briefing
abstract: Another week when Washington was the center of the business world — with consequences for the auto industry, banking, tobacco companies and executive pay.

headline: Union at Globe Files Complaint on Pay Cuts
abstract: The Boston Globe’s largest union filed a complaint with U.S. regulators challenging the 23 percent pay cut the newspaper has set in motion.

headline: Short on Time and Options, Lawyers Remade Chrysler
abstract: In around-the-clock negotiations, a team of lawyers from Jones Day led Chrysler through one of the quickest restructurings on record.

headline: James Cameron’s Presentation at Producers’ Conference is Closed to Press
abstract: A session with director James Cameron before a conference of producers in Hollywood has been suddenly and belatedly closed to the press.

headline: Dutch Bank to Pay Back Madoff Victims, in Part
abstract: Rabobank’s private banking arm is compensating clients for losses on investments made in Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme.

headline: Sara Lee Auction Said to Snub Buyout Funds
abstract: Sara Lee and Goldman Sachs, which is advising the consumer products giant on the auction of its household and personal care business, have prevented the Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts from taking part, The New York Post reported citing unnamed sources.

headline: A New List of How Much AT&T Knows About You
abstract: In a new privacy policy, AT&T details how it tracks the location, TV viewing habits and other activities of its customers.

headline: Judge Rejects G.M. Bondholder Committee Request
abstract: A U.S. bankruptcy judge has denied a request from a small group of General Motors bondholders to become an “official committee” in the bankruptcy case.

headline: A Farewell to Doldrums, a Return to Deals?
abstract: After hitting a low point in April, deal-makers may at last have seen the bottom, Breakingviews says.

headline: Chrysler’s Holdout Lenders Feel the Heat
abstract: After taking a tongue lashing from President Obama, Chrysler’s holdout lenders got a show of support from The Financial Times’s John Gapper.

headline: EBay Plans to Spin Off Skype
abstract: EBay announced plans on Tuesday to spin off Skype, its Internet calling division, in an initial public offering aimed at the first half of 2010.

headline: Upfronts: Jimmy Jabs Jay
abstract: Jimmy Kimmel, the host of ABC’s late night talk show “Jimmy Kimmel Live,” delivered a withering, blistering monologue that took direct aim at ABC, its potential advertisers and his NBC late-night rival, Jay Leno.

headline: Bloggers Love a New Phone You Can’t Have
abstract: Lots of people think the Samsung Android phone is really cool. One catch–you can’t get one here.

headline: Bankruptcy Court Approves Sale of Polaroid Assets
abstract: Polaroid won bankruptcy court approval to sell itself for $88 million to a joint venture led by two liquidation firms.

headline: Britain’s LDV May Get Bid From Telecom Tycoon
abstract: The British van maker LDV, which went into bankruptcy last week, may get a takeover bid from the telecommunications entrepreneur John Caudwell, The Mail on Sunday reported.

headline: Apple Adds Video Recording to the iPhone 3G S
abstract: Apple adds video-recording capabilities and auto-focus to the new iPhone camera.

headline: Me and Jack and Suzy and Twitter
abstract: Getting a Twitter lesson from Jack Welch and fielding questions about Ford.

headline: Apieron Backers Ante Up for Fourth Round
abstract: Apieron, maker of a monitoring device for asthma sufferers, has raised a fourth round of financing from its existing investors.

headline: Q & A: Switching the Zune to Manual Mode
abstract: How to gain better control over your Zune’s syncing protocols.

headline: Motorola’s Jha: Highly Paid, and Elusive
abstract: Sanjay K. Jha, a co-chief executive officer of Motorola, had total compensation of $104 million in 2008. What did he do to earn it?

headline: Buffett Breaks His Own Rule in BYD Deal
abstract: Fortune notes that when Warren E. Buffett decided to invest in BYD, a Chinese producer of rechargeable batteries, electric cars and car parts, last September, the billionaire investor broke one of his own golden rules: Never invest in a business you can’t understand.

headline: What Will Fix the Venture Capital Crisis?
abstract: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

headline: Will Citi’s New Shareholders Head for the Door?
abstract: Citigroup’s upcoming share conversion could be followed by a wave of selling, and that could create an opportunity for bargain hunters, an analyst at Fox-Pitt Kelton said.

headline: Are You Ready for Some Product Placement?
abstract: In its biggest sports installation to date, Sony is equipping the new Dallas Cowboys stadium with more than 3,000 LCD TVs.

headline: Venture Capital’s Elders Say Think Small
abstract: Venture capitalists who began investing in the 1960s have some advice for today’s venture capital firms: think small.

headline: Kerkorian May Put the Mirage on the Block, Report Says
abstract: In an effort to stave off a bankruptcy filing by MGM Mirage, controlling investor Kirk Kerkorian is mulling a sale of the Mirage casino in Las Vegas, The New York Post reported.

headline: Apollo Group Makes Offer for BPP Holdings
abstract: BPP Holdings, a British education and training concern, said on Wednesday that it had received a preliminary approach from Apollo Global valuing it at about 303 million pounds ($447 million). The 620 pence-per-share cash offer represents a 70 percent premium to BPP’s closing price on Tuesday, Reuters reported.

headline: Investors Buy Johnson Products from P&G
abstract: The Procter & Gamble Company has sold its ethnic hair-care products unit, Johnson Products, to a group of investors, including a husband-and-wife team of industry veterans.

headline: Insider Trading at Lehman? Senator Still Wants Answers
abstract: Senator Charles Grassley sent a letter to the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority over its response to allegations of insider trading at Lehman in April 2008.

headline: Q & A: Interesting Points for a GPS
abstract: How to add points of interest to your portable GPS unit.

headline: G.M. Wins Approval to Cut Its Leased Planes
abstract: General Motors has shed one of the items that piqued the ire of Congress last fall: its fleet of leased corporate jets.

headline: U.S. Journalists Sentenced in Korea
abstract: North Korea on Monday sentenced two American journalists to 12 years of hard labor in a case widely seen as a test of how far the isolated Communist state was willing to take its confrontation with the United States.

headline: A Six-Figure Ride for an Outgoing Chief
abstract: Santander Bancorp‘s outgoing chief executive got a car with a book value of more than $100,000, the bank’s proxy statement shows.

headline: Ex-Chief of Schwab Expected to Join Exigen
abstract: David S. Pottruck, the former chief executive of Charles Schwab, is close to joining Exigen Capital, a small technology-focused private equity firm, according to a person briefed on the situation.

headline: Atticus Ends Battle With Deutsche Borse
abstract: Managers of Deutsche Borse may have breathed a measured sigh of relief Tuesday, when Atticus Capital, one of two activist hedge funds that has led a series of battles against the exchange, said it had dumped almost all of its stake.

headline: From the In-Box: More Oscar Nominations
abstract: Reader reaction to Oscar nominations

headline: Bailed-Out C.E.O.s Taking Jets for Personal Use
abstract: The heads of banks that received U.S. money, including Bank of America, Morgan Stanley and Regions Financial, took company jets for personal use, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Another View: A Market-Based Fix for Mortgages
abstract: What to do with all those underwater mortgages? The president of hedge fund firm PSQR Management thinks he has a market-based solution for struggling homeowners.

headline: Global Leveraged Capital Opens Restructuring Advisory Arm
abstract: Global Leveraged Capital, a private investment firm, said on Wednesday it is launching a new restructuring advisory group that will bring a different approach to fundraising at a time when struggling companies have little access to the credit markets.

headline: In G.M.’s Chairman, a Choice Beyond Politics
abstract: In seeking a new chairman for General Motors, the Obama administration turned to a longtime Republican fund-raiser, Edward E. Whitacre Jr., the former chief executive of AT&T.

headline: Hollywood Costume Design Gets Its Own Professor at U.C.L.A.
abstract: Costume design for the movies gets its own professor at UCLA.

headline: Fiat Chief Pressures Unions in Chrysler Talks
abstract: Fiat‘s chief executive said he was ready to abandon plans to form a partnership with Chrysler if the United States car maker’s unions refused to accept substantial cost cuts, The Globe and Mail reported.

abstract: A peek at Berkshire Hathaway‘s annual report shows that Warren E. Buffett is very interested in doing deals — big ones.

abstract: A major stock market rally that sent equities higher around the world on Thursday fizzled in Asia on Friday morning despite fresh data from China suggesting that nation’s downturn is bottoming out.

headline: Twitter Sees Tools, Not Ads, For Revenue
abstract: Twitter is working on various ways to make money from its fast-growing microblogging service, but advertising is an option that is not currently being considered, Reuters reported.

abstract: Even though the U.S. economy remains weak, investors Thursday were already looking ahead to a recovery and setting their sights on inflation.

abstract: Marc Tremblay, who led Sun’s SPARC chip development, left the company last week as Sun was negotiating to sell itself to I.B.M.

abstract: Apple will now only accept mobile apps that work with the upcoming iPhone operating system, 3.0–a sign the new release is getting near.

abstract: Regulators may pave the way for a large group of banks, like JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs, to leave the bailout program far earlier than many had envisioned.

abstract: A hedge fund industry executive and his investment advisory firm have agreed to pay $814,644 to settle charges brought by federal securities regulators that they failed to properly review the Bayou Group when they recommended that their clients invest in the hedge fund before it collapsed.

headline: Scenes From the End of Television (as We Know It)
abstract: Like the transition from typewriter to a computer, the switch from analog to fully digital television revealed a number of unexpected side effects. Because digital signals are more apt to be affected by interference, many viewers in rural areas said they could see fewer stations than they used to.

abstract: Pfizer is looking to conclude deals in emerging markets over “few months” to raise its share in a market estimated at $80 billion, a Pfizer executive told Reuters.

abstract: Advertising agencies trying to fill all the vacant jobs in the digital realm sometimes find themselves facing a dilemma: steal people from other agencies or nurture digital talent from scratch. MDC Partners, which owns Crispin Porter & Bogusky and Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners, and dozens of other agencies, is joining with the University of Colorado at Boulder to create a school to be called Boulder Digital Works.

headline: Ratings: Sluggish Debut for ‘The Unusuals’
abstract: ABC’s new police drama “The Unusuals” made a sluggish debut in the ratings on Wednesday, earning just 6.8 million viewers in its 10 p.m. time slot, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: Hummer Buyer Lobbying Regulators, Report Says
abstract: The potential buyer of General Motors’ Hummer division will begin formal talks with Chinese regulators to seek approval for its acquisition, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Universal Express Boss Loses Appeal
abstract: Richard Altomare, the former chief executive of Universal Express, has lost his appeal to the Supreme Court. On Monday, the court turned down his request to hear his case.

headline: S.E.C. Official Favors Registering Fund Advisers
abstract: A Securities and Exchange Commission official said Monday said he advocated S.E.C. registration for hedge fund advisers, Dow Jones reported.

headline: In Ratings Agencies, Investors Still Trust
abstract: Despite talk of a shake-up for the tainted credit-ratings establishment, things seem to be looking up, not down, for Moody’s.

headline: SVG Capital Taps Fordham as Chief
abstract: SVG Capital, the British private equity firm, has tapped its finance director, Lynn Fordham, to be chief executive, making her one of the highest-profile women in the industry.

headline: Fiat Wants to Avoid Chrysler Product Liability
abstract: Lawyers for Fiat argued Tuesday that in taking over a bankrupt Chrysler, it would be an unfair burden if Fiat had to be responsible for product-liability lawsuits filed over vehicles built by the old Chrysler.

headline: Tidying Up With NeatDesk
abstract: Hardware to keep the desktop clear of clutter.

headline: Advice to M.B.A.’s: Think Different and Don’t Despair
abstract: All over the nation, top business schools have lined up commencement speakers who face a delicate task: Giving a pep talk to graduates, many of whom hope to reap riches on Wall Street, during a time when the Street, and its riches, seem to be shrinking.

headline: Are Flickr Photos Fair Game for Home Printing?
abstract: Following up on the question of whether it’s O.K. to print out photos from Flickr to hang on your wall.

headline: America’s Health Care Priorities II: Doctors, Hospitals and the Quality of Care
abstract: We asked all sorts of experts and stakeholders to answer this question: What should the priorities for health care reform be? Here’s the second batch of answers.

headline: BofA Shareholders Oust Lewis as Chairman
abstract: Shareholders of Bank of America stripped Kenneth D. Lewis of his post as chairman on Wednesday while allowing him to remain president and chief executive, in a vote that may mark the beginning of the end of his leadership at the embattled bank.

headline: Is ‘Buy China’ a Protectionist Threat?
abstract: A free-trade advocate examines the edict attached to China’s stimulus policy.

headline: The Art of Buying in Bearish Times
abstract: Takeover targets look cheap these days, but they may not stay that way. A new white paper from the Boston Consulting Group suggests that potential acquirers should consider seizing the moment.

headline: Unemployment Around the World
abstract: According to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the unemployment in its member countries rose to a level of 7.6 percent in March 2009. Here is an interactive graph of unemployment rates from October 2008 to March 2009 in most of the O.E.C.D. countries.

headline: U.S. Is Said to Oppose Biotech Merger
abstract: CSL, a maker of blood-plasma products, said the Federal Trade Commission recommended legal action to block the proposed $3.1 billion purchase of Talecris Biotherapeutics Holdings.

headline: Microsoft Wants Gadgets to Run Windows
abstract: Microsoft wants to compete with Google’s Android to make operating systems for digital gadgets. But unlike Android and Linux, Windows is not free.

headline: Judge Blocks Transfer of Madoff Property
abstract: The increasingly thorny question of who should be in charge of finding assets and compensating Bernard L. Madoff’s victims touched off a public tug of war among federal judges in Manhattan on Monday — a fight that will determine how victims’ claims will be handled, The New York Times’s Diana B. Henriques reported.

headline: Deadline Passes With No Deal for the Globe
abstract: Negotiations between The New York Times Company and the Boston Newspaper Guild over concessions that could avert the closure of The Boston Globe apparently reached Sunday’s midnight deadline without a deal, Tim Arango of The New York Times reported.

headline: Midway Creditors Call Buyer ‘Wholly Unsuitable’
abstract: Midway Games’ unsecured creditors have asked a bankruptcy judge to examine whether the video game maker’s former owner, Sumner Redstone, and its current owner breached their fiduciary duties with a deal for Mr. Redstone’s stake.

headline: Goldshield of Britain Gets Bid Approaches
abstract: Goldshield Group, the British generic drugs supplier, said it has received bid approaches for the company, sending its shares up 5 percent.

headline: ‘There Can Be Nothing More Toxic’
abstract: Memo to executives: It is risky to tell investors one thing while sending e-mail saying the opposite. Just ask Angelo Mozilo.

headline: TomTom to Raise $600 Million in Offering
abstract: TomTom, largest maker of car-navigation devices in Europe, announced plans to raise $601.4 million in a private rights offering.

headline: Lawmakers Question Treatment of G.M. Bondholders
abstract: Twenty House lawmakers sent a letter to Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner on Friday, arguing that the Obama administration is unfairly favoring General Motors’ workers over its bondholders.

headline: Madoff Investors Who Took Net Loss Won’t Have to Return Cash
abstract: Investors with Bernard L. Madoff who suffered a net loss due to his Ponzi scheme won’t have to return funds they withdrew from his firm in recent years, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing the lawyer charged with recovering the firm’s assets.

headline: Rich Country Within a Poor One, Part 2
abstract: How Congressional districts compare in a measure of their social and economic development.

headline: New in America: Exploring
abstract: Everywhere you turn, you find an Iraqi Chaldean who has fled Iraq along time ago. Some of them have been there for so long they had forgotten Arabic and are now operating on a funny mixture of Chaldean and English, Chaldish!

headline: Skype for iPhone Promises New Features
abstract: Skype launches and app for the iPhone, promises a Blackberry version soon.

headline: Congressman Raises Question About Viper Sale
abstract: As a U.S. court was to hear arguments Friday on the sale of Chrysler to a group including Fiat, the U.S. automaker was engaging in a war of words with a congressman.

headline: Yahoo Remains Mum on Microsoft Talks
abstract: As Yahoo posted a decline in revenue and profit during the first three months of the year, the company’s chief executive, Carol A. Bartz, remained guarded on the subject that investors have been most focused on: The progress of talks with Microsoft over an advertising partnership, which have heated up recently.

headline: Monday Ratings: CBS and ABC Tie
abstract: Season finales of CBS’s comedy line-up on Monday lifted the network into a tie with ABC for first place in the night’s ratings, while the conclusion of “24” failed to boost Fox out of third place, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: Icahn Adds More Debt to His Arsenal
abstract: For Carl C. Icahn, distressed debt is the latest weapon he is amassing as he seeks to exact change at the companies he targets, The New York Post reported.

headline: Marin Software Picks Up $13 Million
abstract: Marin Software, a provider of search marketing technology, said it raised $13 million in a third round of funding led by DAG Ventures.

headline: ‘Go Fish’ for Capitalists
abstract: Forget Old Maid or Go Fish. A new card game, which satirizes the current credit crisis, is much more timely.

headline: Delphi May Sell Assets to Exit Bankruptcy
abstract: Delphi, the auto parts maker that has been in bankruptcy proceedings for the last four years, may sell some of its assets to a third-party buyer, possibly another parts supplier or an investment firm.

headline: HyTrust Launches With $5 Million
abstract: HyTrust, a virtualization start-up, launched its flagship product Monday with $5 million from its backers, VentureBeat reported.

headline: Upfronts: What to Watch This Week
abstract: What to watch for as the networks present their new season schedules this week.

headline: Saab Secures Debt Write-Down Ahead of Takeover
abstract: The Swedish carmaker Saab secured a key court ruling to cut billions of crowns in debt, paving the way for its proposed takeover by the local sportscar maker Koenigsegg.

headline: LED TV Lighting Technology Set to Explode
abstract: As prices drop, LCD TVs using LED lighting technology will explode in popularity, according to a new report from iSuppli.

headline: At Shareholder Meeting, Storms Seem Over for Yahoo
abstract: If Yahoo’s annual meeting of shareholders is a sign of investors’ mood, the storm of controversy that has swirled around the Internet company for more than two years has largely abated.

headline: Kerkorian’s Stake in MGM Mirage Drops
abstract: Kirk Kerkorian may have bought 14.3 million more shares in MGM Mirage, but that wasn’t enough to maintain his majority stake in the casino company as it issued new stock.

headline: High-Tech Antitrust Cases: The Road Ahead
abstract: A $1.4 billion fine against Intel, combined with a tough speech by the Justice Department’s antitrust chief, point to a new day for antitrust enforcement in high-tech markets.

headline: Stanford’s Wife Seeks Say in S.E.C. Lawsuit
abstract: The estranged wife of R. Allen Stanford has asked a judge for permission to intervene in the regulatory lawsuit accusing him of running an $8 billion Ponzi scheme.

headline: Daewoo Engineering Gets Put on the Block
abstract: South Korea’s Kumho Asiana Group said it had decided to put Daewoo Engineering & Construction up for a sale to ease investor worries about liquidity.

headline: Morgan Stanley Posts Loss as Revenue Fell 62%
abstract: Morgan Stanley said Wednesday it posted a net loss of $177 million in the first quarter, compared with a $1.41 billion profit in the comparable period in 2008. Its revenue fell 62 percent, to $3 billion, reflecting year-over-year declines in each of its top-level business divisions.

headline: Times Co. Postpones Threat to Close Boston Globe
abstract: After wringing concessions from all but one of The Boston Globe’s labor unions, The New York Times Company on Monday postponed its threat to start the process of closing The Globe, leaving the newspaper’s immediate future resting on talks with the largest union, the Boston Newspaper Guild.

headline: The Future of E Ink
abstract: From Bits: The introduction of full-color versions of electronic ink displays came closer to reality Monday with the acquisition of E Ink by Taiwan-based Prime View International.

headline: Candover Chairman Apologizes for Missteps
abstract: Candover chairman Gerry Grimstone offered a mea culpa to angry shareholders, after missteps have thrown the future of the private equity firm in doubt.

headline: $175,800 in Tax Help for XTO Energy’s Chairman
abstract: April 15 is a week away, which means there’s lots of last-minute number crunching going on. And as we’ve noted before, chief executives lead complicated lives when it comes to their personal finances.

headline: Shades of Revlon in the SumTotal Feud
abstract: The bidding contest for SumTotal Systems raises some of the same issues that came up in the 1980s Revlon case, The Deal Professor says.

headline: Has G.M. Overextended Its Pension Fund?
abstract: General Motors offered tens of thousands of workers early retirement in its rush to downsize, raising questions about the long-term strength of its pension plan.

headline: Backing Up Data, Simply
abstract: Easy data backup with a new hard drive from Seagate.

headline: The Fog of Cellphone Wars
abstract: The action this year in cellphones will be around Palm and Android, not the carriers.

headline: Start-Up’s Software Goes to Employees for Company Forecasts
abstract: Crowdcast, a start-up, sells software that lets companies run an internal prediction market for things like product ship dates or sales estimates.

headline: How to Be a Photojournalist
abstract: Michael Kamber, one of Baghdad Bureau’s photographic regulars, has just written a post for our sister blog The Lens after a recent trip to Somalia.

headline: TCI Cashes Out of Deutsche Borse
abstract: The Children’s Investment Fund has followed fellow activist hedge fund Atticus Capital in cashing out of Deutsche Borse, bringing an era of battles over the German exchange group to an end, The Financial Times wrote.

headline: Why President Obama Needs to Tweet
abstract: Barack Obama is tossing away the million-member following he’s built on Twitter. It’s a shame, because he’d be way better than Ashton or Oprah.

headline: Ad Start-Up Peer39 Takes $10.5 Million
abstract: Peer39, an online advertising start-up, has lassoed $10.5 million in a third round of funding led by Evergreen Venture Partners.

headline: Q & A: Making Contacts in Outlook
abstract: How to extract contact info from e-mail messages you receive.

headline: Explaining Crisis Responses to ‘a Skeptical Public’
abstract: An essay by a former Treasury official that gives a chronology and explanation for the Bush administration’s responses to the credit crisis.

headline: After AOL Spinoff, Will Time Inc. Be Next?
abstract: Time Warner is inching closer to an untangling of what many consider one of the worst mergers in American corporate history by shedding America Online.

abstract: No game-changing announcements, but an exercise in creating expectations.

headline: Disney Gets In on the Netbook Craze
abstract: Disney’s new netbook offers built-in safety measures for a kid’s Web activity, not to mention an exterior design that would stand out in a conference room.

headline: Debtholders vs. U.S. Over Chrysler Deal
abstract: The Obama administration has entered a tense showdown with several of the nation’s largest banks that appears likely to determine whether Chrysler survives, The New York Times’s Bill Vlasic and David E. Sanger write.

headline: Twitter Trends: Why Do Men Follow Men?
abstract: A study by researchers at Harvard Business School finds some strange gender-related patterns among Twitter users.

headline: Robin Hood Event Adjusts to Tough Times
abstract: By the gilded standards of the hedge fund world, The Robin Hood Foundation’s spring fund-raising event, which has long set the pace for charity benefits, seemed like a lean night out.

abstract: The European Commission on Wednesday fined Intel a record of about $1.45 billion (1.06 billion euros) for abusing its dominance in the market for computer chips to exclude Advanced Micro Devices, which is Intel’s only serious rival.

headline: Chrysler and Fiat Hope for Happy Relationship
abstract: When Daimler-Benz merged with Chrysler in 1998, their leaders told the world to “expect the extraordinary” from the German-American auto giant.

abstract: The potential buyer of General Motors’ Hummer division will begin formal talks with Chinese regulators to seek approval for its acquisition, The Wall Street Journal reported.

abstract: Richard Altomare, the former chief executive of Universal Express, has lost his appeal to the Supreme Court. On Monday, the court turned down his request to hear his case.

headline: App of the Week: WeFi Finds Wi-Fi
abstract: The WeFi app helps you findWi-Fi hot spots to speed Web use on your phone.

headline: HSBC May Put Headquarters and Other Buildings on Block
abstract: HSBC may sell three of its signature office buildings, including its world headquarters at Canary Wharf in London, to raise cash as it tries to avoid a bailout from the British government.

headline: McGraw-Hill’s Charm Offensive
abstract: McGraw-Hill Companies has been the target of some harsh criticism lately, in large part because of the rosy ratings that its Standard & Poor’s unit gave to assets that now look radioactive. (An S&P analyst’s e-mail about rating deals “structured by cows” didn’t help on that score.)

headline: EBay’s Deal History, by the Numbers
abstract: The corporate bosses at eBay’s Silicon Valley headquarters must have their investment bankers on speed dial.

headline: Las Vegas Sands C.E.O. Was Paid $1.28 Million
abstract: Sheldon Adelson received $1.28 million in compensation as chief executive of Las Vegas Sands Corp.  in 2008, 59 percent less than in 2007. Mr. Adelson, the billionaire who is the majority owner of Las Vegas Sands, saw his pay drop amid a 94 percent fall in the company’s stock, according to an Associated Press analysis of a company regulatory filing made Thursday.

headline: Swiss Weigh Tougher Rules on Banks
abstract: Swiss regulators said they were considering new emergency powers that would allow them to break up large banks like UBS and Credit Suisse, in order to wind down troubled business units that are not essential to the economy.

headline: Microsoft’s Project Natal Seeks Poetry in Motion
abstract: Effective motion-sensing technology has been an elusive goal for many gaming manufacturers. Microsoft, however, seems awfully close with its current prototype.

headline: Apple’s App Store Nears One Billion Served
abstract: Apple’s software application store for the iPhone and iPod Touch is nearing its one-billionth download.

headline: First Southern Confirms Private Equity Deal
abstract: Three private equity investors are injecting up to $450 million in First Southern Bancorp, giving them control of a small Florida lender that could be used to acquire more banks.

headline: European Union Approves Vattenfall Takeover of Nuon
abstract: The European Commission approved the takeover of Nuon Energy by the Swedish energy company Vattenfall, on the condition that Vattenfall sell Nuon’s German electricity unit.

headline: Former Harbinger Partner Sues Hedge Fund
abstract: A former partner and chief investment officer at Harbinger Capital Partners is suing the hedge fund in a bid to recover $63 million he claims he is owed as part of his separation agreement, The New York Post reported.

headline: Two Easy Ways to Improve Your iPhone’s Camera
abstract: How to transform iPhone’s mediocre camera into a gallery-worthy shooter.

headline: Ackman Offers Plan to Solve Financial Crisis
abstract: Say tuned. William A. Ackman, the outspoken hedge fund manager, says he has a “plan to save the universe,” or at least the financial universe.

headline: A Medicare-Like Plan for the Non-Elderly
abstract: As a candidate, Barack Obama promised a Medicare-like public health-insurance plan for non-elderly Americans. An economist looks into what’s become of that idea.

headline: MGM Raises $1 Billion in Stock Offering
abstract: MGM Mirage, the struggling casino operator, said Thursday that it had completed a $1 billion public stock offering, part of its announced effort raise $2.5 billion to help it pay down its $14 billion debt load.

headline: ‘SNL’ on the Bank Stress Test Results
abstract: How deeply are the government’s bank stress tests ingrained in pop culture? They were the subject of a “Saturday Night Live” sketch this past weekend.

headline: Despite Citi Losses, a Prince Stays Positive
abstract: Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia has taken a big hit on his Citigroup investment. But in an interview with Prestige magazine, he doesn’t sound like he’s giving up on the banking giant.

headline: G.M.’s Chief Promises Full Details of Restructuring
abstract: The chief executive of General Motors, Fritz Henderson, vowed to Congress that as long as the American taxpayer is its largest investor, “it’s our obligation to be open and transparent in all we do to reinvent G.M.”

headline: From High-Finance Pinnacles to Unemployment Line to Mentors
abstract: How does it feel to plummet from the peaks of global finance to an unpaid gig at a fledgling company? A few dozen laid-off New Yorkers are about to find out.

headline: Get Ready for Your Close-Up
abstract: More businesses and government agencies are looking to video surveillance and facial-recognition technology to make locations more secure.

headline: To Nav and to Nav Not
abstract: Have smartphones made factory-installed car navigation systems a needless and overpriced option?

headline: Financial Unit Weighs on G.E.
abstract: The General Electric Company said Friday that its first-quarter earnings fell 36 percent on sharply lower profits at its troubled finance arm, but the results beat Wall Street forecasts in a glimmer of good news for the struggling company.

headline: Shrinking Finance
abstract: Martin Wolf has some ideas.

headline: G.M. Reaches a Deal With Bondholder Committee
abstract: Update | 1:03 p.m. General Motors said Thursday that bondholders could get a stake of as much as 25 percent in the car maker — an even bigger share than G.M. offered to the United Automobile Workers union — if they don’t oppose G.M.’s reorganization plan.

headline: Cameras With Time-Machine Powers
abstract: David Pogue looks at two new high-speed cameras from Casio: the EX-FC100 and the EX-FS10. Both of them do all that crazy time-machine stuff.

headline: Retiring From A.I.G., but Staying on the Payroll
abstract: American International Group‘s top executive in Asia is retiring this week, but that doesn’t mean he’s leaving the insurance company’s payroll.

headline: Judge Rejects Sale of Coyotes Hockey Team
abstract: A bankruptcy judge has rejected the proposed sale of the National Hockey League franchise the Coyotes to a Canadian billionaire, Jim Balsillie.

headline: Banks Gain Ahead of Stress-Test Results
abstract: Some of the big banks may need billions of dollars in additional capital, but Wall Street decided Wednesday to view the glass of the financial system as half full.

headline: Hey, Verizon Wireless — Free the MiFi!
abstract: Why won’t Verizon put any advance information on the hotly awaited MiFi portable Wi-Fi hotspot?

headline: Hartford’s Capital Plans Weigh on Stock
abstract: Shares of the Hartford Financial Services Group fell Friday after the big property and life insurer said it would take as much as $3.4 billion of federal bailout money and sell up to $750 million of common stock to bolster capital after large losses on investments.

headline: Digital TV Switch Clears the Air for TV on Phones
abstract: The DTV switchover clear analog airwaves for Flo TV to broadcast its phone-specific television signals in more cities.

headline: World’s Fastest Broadband at $20 Per Home
abstract: Super-fast broadband costs $140 a month in the United States. But the cost to upgrade a cable network to the fastest speeds appears minimal.

headline: Madoff Loss Hits Art Aid for Young in Israel
abstract: Disaster is looming for the America-Israel Cultural Foundation, known for its classical music scholarships, as its $14 million endowment was in the hands of Bernard L. Madoff and evaporated in his Ponzi scheme.

headline: Start-Up Hitches a Ride on I.B.M.
abstract: From Ashlee Vance at Bits:

headline: Maybe Ford Does Have a Better Idea
abstract: This small-business delivery van is hot. Not in a Porsche sort of way. But in a this-truck-is-going-to-save-me-money-so-I-can-buy-a-Porsche sort of way.

headline: Sales of Start-Ups Plummet
abstract: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

headline: Circuit City Names Stalking-Horse Bidder
abstract: Circuit City Stores hopes to sell its brand, trademarks and e-commerce business to Systemax, the same company that purchased electronics retailer CompUSA’s intellectual property when it closed in 2008, The Associated Press said.

headline: Reader Response: What Medicare Doesn’t Cover
abstract: A reader asks why “retiree health costs” are such a burden to the Detroit automakers if the retired workers have access to Medicare.

headline: Just 50 I.P.O.’s Come to Market in First Quarter
abstract: In what comes as no surprise to investors, the market for initial public offerings didn’t have a particularly hot first quarter, as the number of I.P.O.’s coming to market continued to drop.

headline: Cerberus Not Mulling Deal for Opel, Report Says
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management has no interest in taking a stake in General Motors‘ Opel business, Reuters reported, citing a source close to the situation.

headline: S.E.C. Is Investigating 150 Hedge Funds
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission is taking a long hard look at hedge funds these days.

headline: Vibe Magazine To Close Down Immediately
abstract: Vibe Magazine, one of the biggest and most influential music magazines in the country, is closing with immediate effect.

headline: British Talent Agency in Talks With Private Equity Firm
abstract: British sports and talent-management agency Formation Group confirmed Tuesday that it was in exclusive talks with Gresham Private Equity about the sale of its businesses.

headline: Scrushy Left HealthSouth in Disarray, Executive Says
abstract: A corporate restructuring expert said in a Birmingham, Ala. courtroom on Thursday that Richard Scrushy, the former chief executive of HealthSouth, left the company in a mess after investigators uncovered a massive fraud there.

headline: Intel Says Outlook Is ‘a Little Better’ Than Expected
abstract: The fortunes of the PC industry are improving, according to Paul Otellini, chief executive of Intel.

headline: Tweaking the Cable Model, to Avoid Newspapers’ Fate
abstract: Cable’s new nightmare is not piracy, but a world where people get TV without paying subscription fees.

headline: 3-D: It’s More Than Pictures With Depth
abstract: 3-D may be creating not just a new technology, but also a new aesthetic.

headline: Greenhill Adds Retail Bankers in London
abstract: Greenhill & Company said it hired two high-level consumer and retail bankers from UBS in London, Seamus Moorhead and Charles Gournay, as the boutique investment bank continues to expand in the wake of the financial crisis.

headline: German Banking Model Obsolete, E.U.’s Kroes Says
abstract: Neelie Kroes, competition commissioner for the European Union, said that Berlin needed to restructure the German financial system, which she called obsolete.

headline: Citi’s Got Talent
abstract: Citigroup wants to step up its role as guidance counselor to its employees by expanding its Global Talent and Performance Management System beyond its senior management, according to an internal memo obtained by DealBook.

abstract: Citigroup may put more employees on commission or offer them larger base salaries as it tries to retain key staffers without running afoul of laws limiting executive pay at banks that receive government funds, Reuters reported.

abstract: Depositions in a lawsuit filed by Donald Trump have shed some light on how the real estate mogul values his vast empire.

headline: State-by-State Unemployment Rates
abstract: A Labor Department report shows that unemployment rose in 46 states in March.

abstract: Uncertainty about Wall Street’s path forward in the face of a shaky U.S. economy caused stocks to wobble Monday.

abstract: There are more Iraqis in charge of key points, these days, with American soldiers only in the vicinity in so-called “overwatch” capacity. Just how much confidence U.S. officials have in that arrangement is made clear by the following Warden Message from the American Embassy.

abstract: Facebook Connect, the social network’s single-sign-on service, snags another site: the mayoral campaign of Michael Bloomberg.

abstract: Managers at the outsourcing company Satyam Computer Services spun an elaborate web of fraud to attract customers and investors, while using stakes in the company to raise cash for themselves, according to a report filed by India’s top investigation agency.

abstract: Perella Weinberg Partners, the boutique investment bank, said on Thursday that it has hired two executives for its burgeoning restructuring group.

abstract: Citi on Wednesday said it is moving forward with a plan to convert a large chunk of its preferred shares into common equity. The long-awaited move is expected to give the United States government a 34 percent ownership stake in the troubled bank.

Now with the team named as Brawn, and with three victories out of four, the scene outside the Brawn motor home has turned into a media zoo – or is it a circus? – which, of course, is not particularly surprising.

headline: Boston Consulting Is Hired to Advise Treasury Auto Team
abstract: The Treasury Department has hired an investment bank and two law firms to advise it on its auto industry plans. So why shouldn’t it hire a management consulting firm as well?

headline: Shares of 2 Banks Decline After Stock Offerings
abstract: Shares of Bank of New York Mellon and U.S. Bancorp fell Tuesday after the two banks sold additional common stock to build up their capital as they begin preparing to pay back government bailout money.

headline: Software Firm Buys Pirate Bay File-Sharing Site
abstract: A small Swedish software provider, Global Gaming Factory, said it had agreed to acquire the Pirate Bay, a file-sharing service whose founders were recently sentenced to prison for assisting in illegal copying.

headline: Emaar, a Dubai Developer, to Merge With Rivals
abstract: The Dubai developer behind the world’s tallest building plans to merge with three rivals owned by the sheikdom’s ruler, in a consolidation aimed at better coping with a global meltdown.

headline: Chinese Efficiency
abstract: China ‘s G.D.P. growth figures show growth, while the electricity figures tell a different story.

headline: Young to Join Lazard as Senior Telecom Banker
abstract: Lazard said Sunday that it had hired George H. Young III, a veteran deal-maker and longtime rainmaker at Lehman Brothers, as its head of global telecommunications.

headline: U.S. Weighs How to Let Banks Give Money Back
abstract: Now that big banks seem to have stabilized, regulators are trying to determine how and when these institutions should be allowed to return their bailout money — and whether such a step might leave banks vulnerable to another crisis should the economy turn for the worse.

headline: British Real Estate Investors Add Life to I.P.O. Market
abstract: As the global market for I.P.O.’s continues to limp along, property vultures in Britain are adding some juice to the scene there, The Financial Times reports.

headline: Like to See the Super Bowl in 3-D at the Multiplex? Soon, Perhaps You Can
abstract: Like to see the Super Bowl in 3-D at your neighborhood multiplex – live? Soon, perhaps you can.

headline: How Will You Future-Proof Your Photos?
abstract: What file formats or other methods can you use to ensure your digital images will stand the test of time?

headline: Dimming the Aura of Goldman Sachs
abstract: Goldman Sachs: It used to be the most respected investment bank in the world. Now, Floyd Norris of The New York Times writes, it seems to be a part of more conspiracy theories than the Central Intelligence Agency.

headline: Another Green Shoot
abstract: Initial jobless claims fell to their lowest level since January.

headline: Speed Up Your Computer’s Graphics
abstract: A video card that is cooler, in more ways than one.

headline: Job Hunting in America
abstract: That has been my life for almost a month now. Up in the morning, surfing all kind of job-finding websites, applying to some and getting stuck on others as I’m asked to provide things that I, as a refugee, don’t have yet.

headline: Dow Closes Rohm Deal and Sells Morton Salt
abstract: Having completed its $16.5 billion buyout of Rohm & Haas, Dow Chemical said Wednesday it would sell Morton Salt to a German fertilizer maker, K+S, in a deal valuing the former Rohm & Haas unit at $1.675 billion.

headline: A.I.G. Sells Japanese Headquarters for $1.2 Billion
abstract: The embattled insurer American International Group said Monday that it was selling its Japanese headquarters to the Nippon Life Insurance Company for $1.2 billion in cash.

headline: Qwest Shares Spike on Report of Possible Deal
abstract: Shares of Qwest Communications International spiked in late trading on Wednesday after a report that the phone company was considering selling its long-haul voice and data network.

abstract: The banks got the bankruptcy law they wanted. Now they should rue that day that happened.

abstract: Responding to DealBook’s column on the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, a partner at hedge-fund firm Vicis Capital raised some interesting questions about the F.D.I.C.’s accounting.

headline: Stanford Points Fingers in $8 Billion Fraud Case

Allen Stanford, the Texas billionaire accused of masterminding an $8 billion Ponzi scheme, tells his side of the story, regulators are lying when they say he defrauded tens of thousands of investors. And if any of it is true, his chief financial officer is to blame, Mr. Stanford says.

abstract: Streamezzo, the provider of a rich application platform for mobile platforms, has nabbed $5.1 million in funding, led by Innovacam.

abstract: CVC Capital has offered to pay just under 2 billion pounds ($3.3 billion) for a 30 percent stake in state-owned postal group Royal Mail, The Sunday Telegraph reported.

abstract: Deutsche Börse‘s shares rose Thursday after a German magazine reported that the company had restarted talks with NYSE Euronext about a possible merger of the two stock-exchange operators. The shares were up 1 percent Thursday, while the broader German markets were trading lower.

abstract: Sadiq Khalaf al-Maliki and the unidentified baby boy that miraculously survived a car bombing.

abstract: A first look at the Kindle DX, the large-format e-reader from Amazon.

abstract: With Anheuser-Busch InBev poised to auction its Central and Eastern European breweries in two weeks, private equity firms are already lining up.

abstract: Barclays’s $13.5 billion deal to sell its Barclays Global Investors to BlackRock, will also translate into a windfall for the British bank’s president, Robert E. Diamond Jr.
