abstract: The U.S. Supreme Court said on Tuesday that it would hear an appeal by Merck of a ruling that reinstated a securities fraud lawsuit involving the company’s disclosures to investors about its withdrawn Vioxx pain drug.

headline: ‘Tarp Cop’ Looking for Cooked Books
abstract: The special inspector-general for the Troubled Asset Relief Program is investigating whether banks have fiddled with their books in order to secure part of the $700 billion in bailout money that the government has handed out, he told The Financial Times in an interview.

headline: Judge Defers Ruling on Madoff’s Restitution
abstract: As he prepares to sentence Bernard L. Madoff next week, a federal judge on Wednesday deferred for three months any decisions on restitution for the thousands of victims of the convicted swindler.

headline: Vodafone Is Said to Consider Buying T-Mobile UK
abstract: Vodafone is considering buying T-Mobile UK in a deal that would create Britain’s biggest mobile phone operator, The Sunday Times and other news outlets reported.

headline: B.N.Y. Mellon in Wings as BGI Talks Advance, Report Says
abstract: As talks advance between Barclays and BlackRock over a deal for the U.K. bank’s asset management business, a potential rival is reportedly ready to step in.

headline: Another View: Seeing Value in Beaten-Down Loans
abstract: Jack Yang, a managing partner at Highland Capital Management, which manages $30 billion in debt investments, offers his views on the current state of the bank loan market.

headline: Bad Cellphone Coverage? It’s Your Own Fault
abstract: An official for a wireless trade group says regulators and even consumers must bear part of the blame for shoddy cell service.

headline: U.S. May Remove Citi’s Pandit, Report Says
abstract: Another report surfaced Thursday suggesting that Citigroup chief executive Vikram Pandit’s job may be in jeopardy.

headline: Wednesday Ratings: ‘Idol’ Narrows Field to Two
abstract: Once an early favorite, Danny Gokey was eliminated on Wednesday’s edition of “American Idol,” leaving just Kris Allen and Adam Lambert to compete next week in the eighth “Idol” finale. The hour-long results episode attracted 24 million viewers for Fox, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: How to Make Your Own Ergonomic Computer Workstation
abstract: With 10 hours and less than $200, one reader was able to create a PC workstation for as little as a tenth of what it would’ve cost him from a catalog.

headline: Hansteen to Raise $314 Million for British Property
abstract: The European real estate group Hansteen Holdings said it would raise about 194.6 million pounds ($314 million) to take advantage of cheaper commercial property in Britain.

headline: Lights! Camera! Advertising!
abstract: The Cinema Advertising Council is distributing a report showing that ad revenue last year increased 5.8 percent from 2007, to $571.4 million from $539.9 million.

headline: Chrysler Is Said to Be Near Deal on Retiree Health Care
abstract: Chrysler is close to a deal with the United Automobile Workers to finance retiree health care that is crucial to the company’s bid for more government aid, The New York Times’s Bill Vlasic reported, citing people with knowledge of the negotiations.

headline: Activists Reject Having It Burger King’s ‘SquarePants’ Way
abstract: Burger King is advertising the Kids Meal to adults in a campaign with an adult approach.

headline: More on Income Levels and Tax Rates
abstract: Readers’ recommendations for more info on effective tax rates for different income levels.

headline: Adviser Sees Profitable Chrysler by 2012
abstract: Chrysler’s restructuring adviser, Robert Manzo, said he sees the restructured company returning to profitability by 2012.

headline: Visual Diary: Home
abstract: The great difference between us is that I have the great luxury to decide my own fate and it was not existential poverty that drove me to come to Iraq.

headline: E-Mails Show Fed Pressure on Bank of America
abstract: E-mails from the Federal Reserve indicate Bank of America’s chief executive was pressed to stay quiet about Merrill Lynch’s financial condition, according to a memo from House Republicans.

headline: Harvard’s Head of U.S. Debt to Leave
abstract: The head of domestic debt investing at Harvard University will leave the Ivy League school’s multibillion-dollar endowment at the end of the month, a Harvard official said Monday.

headline: JPMorgan Tops List of World’s Strongest Banks
abstract: JPMorgan Chase leads a list of the world’s strongest banks, while the Royal Bank of Scotland reported the biggest loss of any lender last year, according to the British magazine The Banker.

headline: GTCR Helps Guide Rudolph Home
abstract: The private-equity firm GTCR Golder Rauner, based in Chicago, is backing an American company that will bring Casper the Friendly Ghost, Lassie and Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer back home to the United States, The Chicago Tribune reported.

headline: Skype Worth More Than $2 Billion, EBay Chief Says
abstract: A price valuation of $2 billion would be low for Skype, the chief executive of its parent, eBay, said on Wednesday, according to Reuters.

headline: Skadden Names 8 New Partners
abstract: Skadden Arps Slate Meagher & Flom, a law firm that frequently advises in big-ticket merger deals, said Thursday it named eight new partners.

headline: When Will Women Become a Work-Force Majority?
abstract: It is possible that, for the first time in American history, women will make up a majority of the labor force late this summer, an economist writes.

headline: Does ‘Financial Innovation’ Hurt or Help the Poor?
abstract: Americans can’t seem to decide: Is making credit available to “subprime” borrowers helping them, or taking advantage of their ignorance? A recent story on credit cards targeting the poor provides one point of contention.

headline: A Quick Bankruptcy for G.M.? Not So Fast
abstract: Any hope of a high-speed bankruptcy by General Motors faces a serious obstacle: a judge — not the Obama administration, not G.M. management and not the company’s creditors — would reign in court, The New York Times’s Jonathan D. Glater writes.

headline: Do-It-Yourself Stress Test?
abstract: Two big banks are in with statements of what the changes in mark-to-market accounting rules will mean for them: nothing.

headline: The Big Number Problem, Part 2
abstract: How many millions are in a trillion? The answer is important for understanding some of the budget battles, but most Americans have trouble comprehending numbers that big.

headline: Thursday Ratings: Another N.B.A. Victory for ABC
abstract: The Los Angeles Lakers’ overtime victory over the Orlando Magic in Game 4 of the NBA Finals helped ABC rank No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday.

headline: K.K.R. Said to Recoup Money on Sun Deal
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts looks set to make its money back on a two-year-old investment in the debt of Sun Microsystems after the technology company agreed to a $7.4 billion deal to be acquired by Oracle, according to press reports.

headline: Will OpenTable Thaw the I.P.O. Market?
abstract: OpenTable offers a price range for its I.P.O. as venture capitalists see signs of a thaw in the public markets.

headline: Questions About Chrysler? Here Are Some Answers
abstract: Who owns Chrysler? Will the new company sell stock? The New York Times’s Micheline Maynard answers some basic questions about Chrysler’s future.

headline: 24 Hours of Racing
abstract: Update | 2:37 p.m.

headline: App of the Week: See if Planes Are Late to the Gate
abstract: FlightTrack puts an airport control tower in the palm of your hand.

headline: White-Collar Jail Terms: Who Got What
abstract: As Bernard L. Madoff, the confessed Ponzi schemer, prepares to learn his sentence today, DealBook takes a graphical look at of some of the longest prison terms for financial fraud.

headline: Shares in Retreat on Fear of Slow Recovery
abstract: Investors took cover in a broad sell-off Monday, as they faced the prospect that any recovery could be slow, and a long way off.

headline: Another Big Round of Layoffs is Imminent at Gannett
abstract: Another big round of layoffs is imminent at Gannett, executives say.

headline: ING Eyes $10 Billion Asset Sale
abstract: The ING Group, the Dutch financial services group, said Thursday that it planned to raise as much as 8 billion euros ($10.6 billion) through asset sales in an effort to reduce risk and focus on Europe, life insurance and retirement services.

headline: Walls Go Tumbling Up… Crumbling Down
abstract: When it comes to security, it’s always easier to escalate than to lower, to add than to subtract. Traditionally and habitually this is what security people do.

headline: Moody’s Reviews UBS for Possible Downgrade
abstract: Moody’s Investors Service said Monday that it was considering whether to lower its credit ratings for the big Swiss bank UBS, which has been hit hard by the financial crisis and faces an investigation by Washington into its American clients’ offshore accounts.

headline: Thud! Ad Spending Declines Reach Double Digits, Nielsen Says
abstract: Advertising spending in the first quarter fell a steep 12 percent compared with the same period a year ago, according to data released Monday afternoon by the Nielsen Company.

headline: Visual Diary: KBR
abstract: Visual Diary: KBR meets CHUs

headline: Dress Barn Adds Tween Brands to Its Wardrobe
abstract: Woman’s apparel maker Dress Barn is trying Tween Brands on for size, in a $157 million deal that has some industry watchers scratching their head.

headline: Judge Rules Jury Should Hear A.I.G. Claims
abstract: A judge ruled that a jury should hear the claims in a case between A.I.G. and Starr International, controlled by Maurice R. Greenberg, the insurer’s former chief executive.

headline: Don’t Blame G.M.’s Creditors
abstract: G.M. bondholders who have hedged their exposures are said to want the carmaker to file for bankruptcy, but that doesn’t make them opportunistic speculators, Breakingviews argues.

headline: Irreversible Damage: Why Little Action on Banking Can Do Great Harm
abstract: The Obama administration is following a “reversible error” strategy, and for this reason is resisting calls to nationalize the banks. But not doing so could cause irreversible damage of a different type, two economists write.

headline: Macs Aren’t Safer, Just a Smaller Target
abstract: Most Macs aren’t affected by viruses and malware, but that doesn’t mean Mac users can’t make their computers more secure.

headline: For Perelman, a Friendly Separation Turns Sour
abstract: Ronald O. Perelman, the billionaire and cosmetics mogul, knows a thing or two about messy breakups. This time, though, his stormy separation involves a former business partner, not a former love interest.

headline: The Granddaddy State
abstract: Protests about the size of the budget, and the burden it will leave on our “grandchildren,” imply that the current generation borrows and future generations pay. But borrowing creates assets as well as liabilities—and future generations will inherit both, an economist writes.

headline: A.I.G. Squeezes Charities to Pay Bonuses, Report Says
abstract: The American International Group is seeking control of a $490 million charitable endowment, as well as trying to get back $27 million it has handed out to New York charities, in order to pay executive bonuses, The New York Post reported.

headline: Securitized Debt Makes a Comeback in Japan
abstract: Takefuji, one of the largest consumer lenders in Japan, aims to raise as much as $1 billion by securitizing its loan book and borrowing.

headline: BofA Said to Lose Another Top Merrill Banker
abstract: Bank of America has reportedly lost yet another senior Merrill Lynch banker.

headline: A Failure of Regulation, Not Capitalism
abstract: Financial market regulation failed to protect taxpayers from the costs of bailing out investors, an economist writes.

headline: Benjamin Edwards, Brokerage Figure, Dies at 77
abstract: Benjamin F. Edwards III, who transformed A. G. Edwards, the St. Louis brokerage house founded by his great-grandfather, into the largest United States brokerage company based outside New York, died Monday in Naples, Fla. He was 77 and lived primarily in St. Louis, with a second home in Naples.

headline: Nomura Executives See Pay Drop by 55 Percent
abstract: Nomura Holdings said its top executives’ pay fell 55 percent in the year ended March 31 from a year earlier as the largest Japanese brokerage house posted a record loss.

headline: Singapore’s Temasek Defends Costly BofA Exit
abstract: Temasek, Singapore’s investment fund, defended its money-losing exit from Bank of America, saying the United States-centric bank did not fit its investment criteria and the risk was perceived to be greater than the expected return.

headline: Fortis Investors (Calmly) Accept BNP Offer
abstract: Fortis shareholders in the Netherlands voted Wednesday to back a takeover by the French bank BNP Paribas, overcoming a revolt by minority investors and ending the run of Fortis as a ward of the Belgian state.

headline: Disney Gets In on the Netbook Craze
abstract: Disney’s new netbook offers built-in safety measures for a kid’s Web activity, not to mention an exterior design that would stand out in a conference room.

headline: Debtholders vs. U.S. Over Chrysler Deal
abstract: The Obama administration has entered a tense showdown with several of the nation’s largest banks that appears likely to determine whether Chrysler survives, The New York Times’s Bill Vlasic and David E. Sanger write.

headline: Twitter Trends: Why Do Men Follow Men?
abstract: A study by researchers at Harvard Business School finds some strange gender-related patterns among Twitter users.

headline: Robin Hood Event Adjusts to Tough Times
abstract: By the gilded standards of the hedge fund world, The Robin Hood Foundation’s spring fund-raising event, which has long set the pace for charity benefits, seemed like a lean night out.

headline: Intel Fined Record $1.45 Billion in Antitrust Case
abstract: The European Commission on Wednesday fined Intel a record of about $1.45 billion (1.06 billion euros) for abusing its dominance in the market for computer chips to exclude Advanced Micro Devices, which is Intel’s only serious rival.

headline: Chrysler and Fiat Hope for Happy Relationship
abstract: When Daimler-Benz merged with Chrysler in 1998, their leaders told the world to “expect the extraordinary” from the German-American auto giant.

headline: Hail Our Alma Mater, Dear Old MDCU
abstract: Advertising agencies trying to fill all the vacant jobs in the digital realm sometimes find themselves facing a dilemma: steal people from other agencies or nurture digital talent from scratch. MDC Partners, which owns Crispin Porter & Bogusky and Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners, and dozens of other agencies, is joining with the University of Colorado at Boulder to create a school to be called Boulder Digital Works.

headline: Ratings: Sluggish Debut for ‘The Unusuals’
abstract: ABC’s new police drama “The Unusuals” made a sluggish debut in the ratings on Wednesday, earning just 6.8 million viewers in its 10 p.m. time slot, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: Hummer Buyer Lobbying Regulators, Report Says
abstract: The potential buyer of General Motors’ Hummer division will begin formal talks with Chinese regulators to seek approval for its acquisition, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Universal Express Boss Loses Appeal
abstract: Richard Altomare, the former chief executive of Universal Express, has lost his appeal to the Supreme Court. On Monday, the court turned down his request to hear his case.

headline: Blog Post on Bank Stress Tests Adds to Worries
abstract: Did a dire posting on an obscure blog about the Treasury’s bank stress tests contribute to Wall Street’s sell-off of financial stocks on Monday?

headline: A.I.G. in $25 Billion Deal With New York Fed
abstract: American International Group, the bailed-out U.S. insurance company, announced Thursday that it had reached an agreement to reduce its debt with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York by $25 billion.

headline: Fox Says It Won’t Show Obama Press Conference
abstract: For the first time in Barack Obama’s presidency, a broadcast network is declining to televise one of his prime time press conferences.

headline: Q&A: Friday Tip of the Week — Using Outlook for Facebook
abstract: TechHit’s FBLook add-in puts an extra line on the toolbar that lets you update your status right from Outlook

headline: From the Inbox: Another Happy Customer
abstract: Bob M. writes… The high quality crystal clear DTV images are incredible… except…

headline: Upfronts: ABC Renews ‘Better Off Ted,’ ‘Castle’ and ‘Scrubs’
abstract: ABC renewed the long-running series “Scrubs,” the new sitcom “Better Off Ted” and the new drama “Castle” ahead of its upfront presentation.

headline: Sun Is Said to Cancel Big Chip Project
abstract: Sun Microsystems has canceled its Rock chip project after years of funding and toil, according to two people briefed on the matter.

headline: Hedge Fund Chides Chemed Over Jet Deal
abstract: MMI Investments‘ proxy battle with Chemed heated up Thursday, as the two sides traded barbs over Chemed’s purchase of a new corporate jet.

headline: At Midnight, Analog Age of Television Ends
abstract: Television states across the United States are now expected to be broadcasting solely in digital form, bringing an end (with caveats) to the analog signals that have delivered TV shows to viewers for the better part of a century.

headline: Odds of Depression (and Various Other Things)
abstract: Intrade puts the odds of a depression at 20 percent.

headline: Texas Financier and Antiguan Official Accused of Fraud
abstract: R. Allen Stanford, the Texas billionaire, and a former Antiguan regulatory official have been indicted on fraud and obstruction charges related to a $7 billion Ponzi scheme, the Justice Department said.

headline: Monster Settles S.E.C. Backdating Charges
abstract: Monster Worldwide, which runs the Monster job search Web site, has agreed to pay $2.5 million to settle federal civil charges that it secretly backdated options for its executives and employees.

headline: Intel’s Strategy Won’t Change Despite Antitrust Charges
abstract: Intel says it won’t change any of its practices despite a massive antitrust fine imposed by European regulators.

headline: Atticus Joins SAC to Take Stake in Sotheby’s
abstract: The latest hedge fund to bet on an auction house is Atticus Capital, which joins SAC Capital as a shareholder in Sotheby’s.

headline: Japan Pension Fund May Sell Bonds to Back Payments
abstract: Japan’s public pension fund, the world’s largest with about $1.2 trillion in reserves, said it may sell Japanese government bonds this year to cover payments, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Kmart Confidential: Jury Finds ex-C.E.O. Liable
abstract: A federal jury on Monday found the former chief executive of Kmart, Charles C. Conaway, liable for misleading investors about the company’s cash crisis in the months before its 2002 bankruptcy.

headline: Twitter Spreads Scoops — and Falsehoods
abstract: In the Amazon book delisting debacle, Twitter spread news and misinformation with equal efficiency.

headline: Dead Man’s Curve
abstract: If I ran a radio station, the bankruptcy filing by General Motors would be marked by a day of songs inspired by the company that once dominated America’s wheels-based culture.

headline: In Europe, a Glimpse at Obstacles to Financial Reform
abstract: As Mr. Obama announced a regulatory overhaul, a squabble between Brussels and Britain over financial markets and firms — many based in London — showed how difficult global regulatory reform is likely to be.

headline: Google’s Black-Box Social Network
abstract: Google is tapping vanity to get people to use its social network: If you fill out a profile, people will see it if they search for your name.

headline: More Facebook Phishing Trouble
abstract: The social network is fighting off cybercriminals again today.

headline: The Economic Impact of Climate Change
abstract: A report released today by the Obama administration paints a dire picture of the economic consequences from global climate change.

headline: At Southern Union, a President With Ties to a Law Firm
abstract: When Eric D. Herschmann was named last May as president and chief operating officer of Southern Union, a Houston-based natural gas company, he continued to be a partner at the law firm of Kasowitz, Benson, Torres & Friedman. Southern Union also happens to be a very good client of the law firm, where Mr. Herschmann has been a partner since 1996, according to the company’s recent proxy.

headline: Buffett Offers Preview of Berkshire Earnings
abstract: Warren E. Buffett says his holding company, Berkshire Hathaway, will report a roughly 10 percent drop in its first-quarter operating profit next week.

headline: Ex-Clients Sue Lehman on Auction-Rate Securities
abstract: Lehman Brothers Holdings is being sued by two former clients for more than $190 million, alleging the failed bank deceived them about the market for auction-rate debt.

headline: Arcade Publishing, With Venerable History of Fighting Censorship, Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: Arcade Publishing, with a venerable history of fighting censorship, files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy after the death of one of its founders.

headline: Biogen Says 2 Proxy Advisory Firms Support Its Slate
abstract: Biogen Idec on Sunday said two proxy advisory firms recommend shareholders of the biotechnology company vote against billionaire Carl C. Icahn’s slate of candidates for its board.

headline: AbitibiBowater Is Said to Seek New Deal on Debt
abstract: AbitibiBowater, the giant newsprint company, remained locked in talks with its lenders on Friday as it tried to devise a new reorganization plan for its mountainous debt, The New York Times’s Michael J. de la Merced reported, citing people briefed on the negotiations.

headline: Observer Media Said to Buy Stake in Very Short List
abstract: Jared Kushner’s Observer Media Group has snapped up an 80 percent stake in the Very Short List, the e-mail tip sheet owned by Barry Diller’s media conglomerate I.A.C., The New York Post reported.

headline: Can Kerkorian Stage a Comeback?
abstract: The sagging economy has clobbered Kirk Kerkorian’s empire, but don’t count him out just yet.

headline: Another Oscar Change, This Time in Original Song Category
abstract: The Oscar folks make another rules change, this time in the best original song category.

headline: G.M.’s Stock Plummets After Disclosure of Insider Sales
abstract: General Motors’ stock plunged more than 22 percent to a 76-year low on Tuesday, a day after a group of G.M. executives disclosed they had sold shares in the struggling automaker.

headline: G.M.’s Big Day in Bankruptcy Court
abstract: General Motors is heading to bankruptcy court Tuesday to seek approval to sell its assets to a “New G.M.” in a plan to reinvigorate the automaker under U.S. government ownership, Reuters said.

headline: Senior Citi Banker Heads to Credit Suisse
abstract: A senior investment banker at Citigroup who worked on major bank deals is leaving to become vice chairman of Europe, the Middle East and Africa investment banking at Credit Suisse, according to an internal Credit Suisse memo obtained by Reuters.

headline: Clean Technology Venture Funding Fell 48% in First Quarter
abstract: Venture investment in cleantech start-ups plunged in the first quarter of 2009 to a level last seen in 2006.

headline: Retail Sales: Much Ado About . . .
abstract: Retail sales are still bad, but they are not as bad as a few months ago.

headline: Shareholders Support Target Over Ackman
abstract: Shareholders of the retail giant Target delivered a stinging defeat to the activist investor William A. Ackman on Thursday, re-electing all of the company’s nominees to the board in one of the most closely watched proxy contests of the season.

headline: Another ‘McFlurry Moment’ for ’30 Rock’
abstract: Were all the mentions of “Mamma Mia” on Thursday’s “30 Rock” an example of product placement?

headline: MassMutual Distances Itself from Madoff Hedge Fund Losses
abstract: Investors in the firm run by disgraced financier Bernard L. Madoff have filed 18 lawsuits against Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance in an effort to recoup $3.3 billion that its hedge fund group lost in the scandal. But the Springfield, Mass.-based insurer is trying to distance itself from the ordeal and says it has no liability in the matter, The Boston Globe reported.

headline: Group Seeks Bankruptcy For Madoff
abstract: A small group of investors took Bernard L. Madoff to bankruptcy court on Monday, saying the disgraced financier had bilked them out of nearly $64 million.

headline: Magna Said to Reach Deal for G.M.’s European Unit
abstract: Negotiators from General Motors, Magna and the German government reached a tentative agreement on Friday that would see Magna take a major stake in G.M.’s European operations, The New York Times reported Friday, citing a person briefed on the talks.

headline: Facebook Said to Reject Funding Offer
abstract: Facebook‘s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, after a board-level conversation, has declined a funding offer that would value the social network firm at $4 billion, VentureBeat reported.

headline: U.S. Considers Broad Financial Pay Guidelines
abstract: Obama administration officials are contemplating a major overhaul of the compensation practices in the financial services industry, moving beyond banks to include more loosely regulated hedge funds and private equity firms, The New York Times reported.

headline: Hertz Shares Drop on Plans for Stock and Debt Sale
abstract: Shares of Hertz Global Holdings tumbled on Wednesday after the car and equipment rental company announced that it plans to sell shares and convertible notes to raise cash.

headline: Fuld Resigns as Lehman’s Chairman
abstract: Richard S. Fuld Jr., the former chief executive of Lehman Brothers, submitted his resignation as chairman on May 14, almost eight months to the day since the securities firm filed for bankruptcy, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday.

headline: Le Mans-ell and Prost in the Sarthe
abstract: Just watching the Le Mans 24 Hours race practice session on Eurosport in France. Le Mans takes place this weekend, and I’m looking forward to taking it in. As I watch at the moment I was prompted to note just a couple of things. The first is the interesting thing about how Peugeot is attacking Audi over what they consider is a car that does not conform to the rules, particularly in the area of aerodynamics. Sound familiar? Yes, it’s the Le Mans version of the double diffuser in F1.

headline: How Bloomberg Knows Who’s Not a Killer
abstract: Want to stay safe in New York City? If Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s theory is right, you may want to surround yourself with readers of The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Skechers and the Six-Figure Car Deal
abstract: Skechers, the footwear company known for its inexpensive but fashionable shoes, has expensive taste when it comes to some things — like cars.

headline: Formula One’s Cleaner but Very Slow Hybrids
abstract: Formula One has introduced an energy-saving device known as Kinetic Energy Recover Systems that is supposed to show off how the series is moving toward environmentally relevant technology. But this season, no KERS car has won a race.

headline: Link by Link: When Censoring, Mind the Kittens
abstract: The Iranian government is carrying out an Internet crackdown in hopes of subduing the protest movement that has surged since the disputed results of the presidential election on June 12. If only Iran’s leaders had thought through the implications of what can be called the Cute Cat Theory of Internet Censorship, as propounded by Ethan Zuckerman, a senior researcher at the Berkman Center for Internet and Society at Harvard Law School.

headline: The More Things Change . . .
abstract: Mencken on governors: “It would be hard to find any other class of presumably reputable men who show so high an average of rogues and charlatans.”

headline: Private Equity Treads Cautiously In Bankruptcy Quagmire
abstract: Picking over the carcasses of bankrupt companies is tempting for private equity firms, but the more traditional buyout shops are showing caution bidding on assets entangled in the courts, Reuters says.

headline: Forbes: A ‘Capitalist Tool’ That’s Pinching Pennies
abstract: The Forbes brand and the family behind it, both long synonymous with riches and success, are feeling the financial crisis.

headline: Elevation Said to Shift Strategy for Forbes Investment
abstract: Elevation Partners, the private equity firm that shelled out about $300 million for a 40 percent stake in Forbes Media in 2006, is shifting gears on the investment, The New York Post reported.

headline: V.C.’s Invest $6 Million in Cloudera
abstract: Cloudera, an data storage and management start-up, has nabbed $6 million in a second round of financing led by Greylock Partners.

headline: Choosing Its Own Path, Ford Stayed Independent
abstract: On Nov. 29, 2006, Ford Motor made a surprising pitch to the nation’s biggest banks. In a packed ballroom at a New York hotel, Ford’s chief executive, Alan R. Mulally, said he would mortgage all the company’s assets for billions of dollars in loans to finance an overhaul of the troubled automaker. Although the economy was healthy then, Mr. Mulally said the money would give Ford “a cushion to protect for a recession or other unexpected event.”

headline: How TLC Secured Sullenberger’s Story
abstract: Capt. Chelsey B. Sullenberger will be interviewed for a documentary about his life for the cable channel TLC.

abstract: Lawyers for a group of Bernard L. Madoff’s victims are asking a judge to reject the way their losses in the fraud are calculated, and base them on Madoff’s fictional balances instead.

headline: The Dartmouth Debate (Cont.)
abstract: Amitabh Chandra, a Harvard economist, takes on critics of the Dartmouth Health Atlas and its analysis of geographic variations in medical spending.

headline: Form 1040’s Neglected Kid Sister
abstract: As federal and state individual income tax returns come due, they overshadow the Social Security tax, which brings in almost as much revenue, an economist writes.

abstract: Disney’s new netbook offers built-in safety measures for a kid’s Web activity, not to mention an exterior design that would stand out in a conference room.

headline: Is Entrepreneurship Really That Easy?
abstract: The Kauffman Foundation is making a three-year $9.5 million investment “to assist auto suppliers and advance entrepreneurship.” It claims that the program will create 1,200 new companies, generate 5,000 new jobs, save 20,000 existing jobs, and generate $300 million in spending. Really?

headline: Co-Anchor of ‘Nightly Business Report’ to Depart

Schwartz reported.

abstract: The question came the other day from an old friend with a one-man business: “How much money do I need to retire?” I get asked this a lot. So I came up with an answer: “Three million dollars.”

headline: Ken Lewis, the Master Government Negotiator
abstract: Bank of America’s Kenneth Lewis has made some questionable private deals, but he is a master at negotiating with the government and leveraging a weak hand to cover his missteps, The Deal Professor says.

headline: $80,000 for a Year Off? She’ll Take It!
abstract: This year may be a disastrous one for the global economy, but it’s shaping up to be one of the best that Heather Eisenlord has enjoyed in a good long while. Granted, that might not be saying much: For the past five years, Ms. Eisenlord has been an associate at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, a notably grueling place for a lawyer to work.

headline: Robert Reich on Power
abstract: The former labor secretary says power is missing from the discussion about the financial rescue.

headline: BofA May Need $36.6 Billion, Analysts Say
abstract: Bank of America may need to raise much as $37 billion in additional capital later this year to bring an important ratio in line with its peers, according to analysts at Oppenheimer.

headline: Fed Scales Back Some Lending Programs
abstract: The Federal Reserve moved for the first time to scale back several emergency lending programs started last fall, at the height of the financial crisis.

headline: Larger Kindle Due This Week
abstract: New Kindle arrives just three months after previous version.

headline: As Furor Over Palin Joke Rages, Letterman Rises in the Ratings
abstract: As the furor raged over a joke David Letterman made about Sarah Palin and her daughter, and the Alaska governor accepted the talk-show host’s apology, Letterman’s posted his best ratings yet against rival Conan O’Brien.

headline: Quattrone’s Firm Coaches Tech Firm in Bid Battle

headline: NetLogic Snaps Up Raza, a Processor Maker
abstract: NetLogic Microsystems has agreed to buy Raza Microelectronics, a maker of processors designed for communication devices, for $183.4 million in stock.

abstract: Fiat‘s chief executive, fresh from his deal for Chrysler, was in Berlin on Monday to determine whether he might add to his kingdom by acquiring General Motors‘ European operations.

headline: Plan to Sell Chrysler to Fiat Clears Bar

Glater reported.

headline: Wachovia’s Ex-Chief Lands P.E. Job
abstract: G. Kennedy Thompson, the former chief executive of Wachovia who was pushed out after disastrous losses, has taken a job as an adviser at a New York private equity firm.

In a report on its Web site, the newspaper said the two companies were in discussion over an arrangement in which American Airlines would sell Citi a block of frequent-flier miles in advance.

headline: S.E.C. Says 4 Partners Ran $11 Million Ponzi Scheme

headline: Visual Diary: ‘This One Dead’

abstract: For those of you with little time in your day for a small northeastern European country, give pause to consider what Latvia is going through.

abstract: Investors are unlikely to know the results of the government’s stress tests of major banks until May 4, but Wall Street cleared one hurdle on Friday: stocks did not lose their footing after regulators laid out how they were conducting the assessments.

headline: Report: Digital Spending to Keep Climbing
abstract: A new report, the 10th annual such forecast from PricewaterhouseCoopers, expects even more of a fractionated media marketplace thanks to the quickening pace of change to digital delivery of everything from video clips of skateboarding dogs to books to games.

headline: 2 Casino Giants Amend Debt Agreements
abstract: Casino companies Wynn Resorts and Las Vegas Sands each said Tuesday that they amended their debt agreements to get more breathing room as they repay billions of dollars in notes.

headline: Weinstein Company Looks To Retool
abstract: Last week, the privately owned Weinstein Company had hired Miller Buckfire, a financial consultant based in New York, to help restructure its finances.

headline: Expert Tips on Photographing Your Pets
abstract: A professional pet photographer shares the tricks of the trade.

headline: Obama, in Europe, Faces Big Challenges to Agenda
abstract: For nearly 30 years, American presidents have arrived at economic summit meetings with nearly identical talking points: the solution to most ailments lies in more economic integration, unleashing free markets and using a light touch to tame capitalism.

headline: A ‘Safe Haven’ Looks Less Secure
abstract: Government bonds, once a safe haven, no longer look quite so secure, Breakingviews says.

headline: The HuffPo Parody: Wemple Responds
abstract: Eric Wemple, the editor of The Washington City Paper, responds to Arianna Huffington’s post on the City Paper’s HuffPo parody.

headline: Chrysler Takes First Steps in Bankruptcy Court
abstract: Deliberations on the fate of Chrysler shifted from Washington to a Manhattan courtroom on Friday as lawyers for the automaker sought to clear the way through bankruptcy, sell or transfer Chrysler’s operations, and keep paying its workers their salaries and benefits.

headline: SumTotal Chooses Rival Bid From Vista
abstract: A new winner emerged in the battle to acquire SumTotal Systems on Wednesday, after the firm said that it was walking away from a deal with Accel-KKR and was instead selling itself to rival bidder Vista Equity.

headline: Cnooc Said to Enlist Goldman in Kosmos Bid
abstract: Cnooc, China’s top offshore oil and gas producer, has hired Goldman Sachs to advise it on a bid for a stake in Kosmos Energy, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Intel’s Odd Role as a Lead Linux Promoter
abstract: Intel is happy to stay in the background, letting folks like Novell and Canonical do with Moblin what they will. It’s a stance that ruffles Microsoft’s feathers a bit less.

headline: Troubled U.S. Savings and Loans Increase, but Losses Narrow
abstract: Losses at U.S. savings-and-loan associations narrowed in the first quarter, but the number of institutions in trouble increased.

headline: Is Higher Steel Production a ‘Green Shoot’?
abstract: The steel industry certainly contributed to the economy’s collapse in the fall and winter months. As the crisis unfolded, steel production fell precipitously. But now output is gradually rising, which should be good news, and is…but not entirely.

headline: In Victory for Icahn, Amylin Chairman Is Ousted
abstract: The billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn and the hedge fund Eastbourne Capital Management have succeeded in ousting the chairman of Amylin Pharmaceuticals as well as its lead independent director, giving them a bigger-than-expected victory in their hard-fought proxy fight.

headline: Asustek Vows to Out-Apple Apple
abstract: Asustek, which pioneered the netbook, is dreaming big, hoping to offer everything from smartphones to game consoles.

headline: Munger of Berkshire Calls for Ban on Credit Swaps
abstract: Berkshire Hathaway’s vice chairman, Charlie Munger, said Friday that he supported an outright ban of credit default swaps to prevent speculators from profiting on the failure of companies.

headline: Would Geffen See a Times Co. Investment as Charity?
abstract: Some industry observers say that David Geffen’s reported interest in buying a stake in The New York Times Company is less a business move than a philanthropic investment.

headline: Finance Columnist’s Financial Adviser Charged With Fraud
abstract: Matthew Weitzman, a money manager who ran a financial planning firm, has been arrested on charges of defrauding clients of more than $6 million.

headline: Q & A: Putting Words to Pictures
abstract: How to make, store and share a photo slideshow, complete with backing audio.

headline: Investor to Sue JP Morgan Chase for Subprime Losses
abstract: Len Blavatnik plans to file a lawsuit against JPMorgan Chase, accusing the bank of mismanaging $1 billion owned by his industrial holding company, Access Industries.

headline: Ex-Chief of Investment Firm Is Indicted
abstract: Federal prosecutors on Thursday indicted a former top executive of a prominent investment firm on charges involving questionable tax shelters made and sold by the firm up until 2006.

headline: Hedge Fund Founder Ordered to Pay $62 Million in S.E.C. Case
abstract: Michael Lauer, the founder of the hedge fund Lancer Management Group, was ordered by a judge on Friday to pay $62 million to investors after being found liable for fraud last fall in a case brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Live-Blogging the G.M. News Conference
abstract: 9:55 a.m. | Last Questions: Mr. Henderson is asked by Sharon Silke Carty of USA Today how many bondholders might have credit default swaps that would protect them if G.M. files for Chapter 11. He won’t give a number. That’s an important question, given the suspicion by analysts that many bondholders are balking because they have an ace in the hole.

headline: No Entrants Yet in Contest for 60-Watt LED Bulb
abstract: The race to develop an LED replacement for a standard 60-watt light bulb is still wide open, says the Department of Energy, sponsor of the L Prize contest.

headline: Lewis Said to Testify That U.S. Urged Silence on Merrill Deal
abstract: Kenneth D. Lewis, the chief executive of Bank of America, testified under oath that the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben Bernanke, and then-Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson pressured him to not discuss its plan to buy Merrill Lynch, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Judge Rejects Patriarch Bid to Overturn Polaroid Auction
abstract: A federal judge rejected a bid to block the sale of Polaroid for $87.6 million to a joint venture led by two liquidation firms.

headline: Peeking Under the Hood of the iPhone 3G S
abstract: More than half of the components inside the new iPhone model have been tweaked or changed, says a man who flew to Paris to take one apart.

headline: Help! I Have No TV Picture!
abstract: The transition to digital television broadcasting is now complete. Here’s what to do if you’re not prepared.

headline: Visual Diary: Carpets, Bombing
abstract: A slight spike in attacks throughout Baghdad is a worrying sign ahead of the proposed June 30th withdrawal of U.S. troops from most Iraqi cities.

headline: New G.M. Chief Doesn’t Rule Out Bankruptcy
abstract: A week into his new job as chief executive of General Motors, Fritz Henderson said on Sunday he was confident in the future of the company but a structured bankruptcy remains a possibility, The New York Times’s A. G. Sulzberger reported.

headline: Chrysler’s Fall May Help Obama to Reshape G.M.
abstract: Fresh from pushing Chrysler into bankruptcy, President Obama and his economic team are hoping that the hard line they took last week gives them leverage to force huge changes in General Motors, a far larger and more complex company.

headline: Star Tribune Co. Files Bankruptcy Reorganization
abstract: The Star Tribune Co. says it has filed a reorganization plan in U.S. Bankruptcy court, with the goal of emerging from Chapter 11 protection this fall.

headline: HealthSouth Civil Lawsuit Seeks $2.6B From Scrushy
abstract: Shareholders want HealthSouth‘s founder, Richard M. Scrushy, to pay $2.6 billion for his alleged role in a huge fraud that nearly ruined the rehabilitation company, lawyers told a judge Monday.

headline: A Cablevision Spinoff Could Shake Up Leagues
abstract: If Cablevision Systems decides to go ahead with a spinoff of its Madison Square Garden business, the deal would reverberate through the world of professional sports, The New York Times’s Ken Belson writes.

headline: Q & A: Creeping File Sizes in iTunes
abstract: Changes in file formats can affect the size of your music files. Here’s how to tweak them so you get the most bang for the byte.

headline: Obama Proposes New Financial Regulations
abstract: President Obama proposed a new regulatory structure for the U.S. financial system, declaring that it is needed to protect the rights of ordinary consumers and to guard against the practices that led to the financial crisis.

headline: Will the Phone Industry Need a Bailout, Too?
abstract: As the number of traditional phone lines falls rapidly, the possibility is rising that the telephone industry will need a government bailout.

headline: SemGroup Examiner Pins Collapse on Former Managers
abstract: The United States energy trader SemGroup spiraled into bankruptcy last year after its top executives lied about its liquidity problems and mismanaged a speculative trading strategy, Reuters said, citing a report released by the company’s court-appointed examiner on Wednesday.

headline: Underwriters Set to Earn $500 Million in Next Few Weeks, Report Says
abstract: As Wall Street banks rush to raise capital after hearing the results of the “stress tests,” financial institutions are looking at a $500 million fee bonanza in just a few weeks for helping rivals raise equity, The Financial Times reported.

headline: A Poor Forecaster Gets One Right (Sort of)
abstract: The German finance minister can probably rightly be criticized for making a few poor financial predictions. But at least he was calling for more market transparency way back before the crisis erupted — transparency that might have helped him, and others, produce better predictions.

headline: Is Kleinwort Benson Set for a Fade Out?
abstract: The real selling point of Kleinwort Benson, the investment bank that Commerzbank has put on the block, could be its name, Breakingviews says.

headline: Extended Stay Lenders Say Firms Engineered Bankruptcy
abstract: Two of Extended Stay Hotels’ junior lenders have accused Cerberus Capital Management and Centerbridge Partners of scheming to force the hotel chain into bankruptcy in order to take over the company’s properties, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: BofA Reported to Pay Big Bonuses to Retain Bankers
abstract: Bank of America has been paying millions in bonuses to lure talent and retain investment bankers whom the company views as vital, The New York Post reported.

headline: Value: Worthless.  Market Price: $458 Million.
abstract: G.M. shares are worthless — and have a market value of nearly half a billion dollars.

headline: American Airlines Said to Open Talks on Easing Loans
abstract: American Airlines, struggling with slumping demand, asked lenders to ease the terms of its $435 million loan, people familiar with the request told Bloomberg News.

headline: Cuomo’s Inquiry and Buyout Firms
abstract: Andrew M. Cuomo is on a winning streak.

headline: G.M. Affiliate Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: Chevrolet-Saturn of Harlem became the first affiliate of General Motors to seek Chapter 11 protection as the carmaker prepares for a massive government-sponsored restructuring.

headline: Stress-Test Assumptions May Be Too Rosy, Regulator Says
abstract: The adverse scenario used to test the health of the 19 largest American banks is “disturbingly close” to current economic conditions, sparking a concern that there might need to be a second stress test, a financial bailout fund watchdog said Monday.

headline: Disney Gets In on the Netbook Craze
abstract: Disney’s new netbook offers built-in safety measures for a kid’s Web activity, not to mention an exterior design that would stand out in a conference room.

headline: Debtholders vs. U.S. Over Chrysler Deal
abstract: The Obama administration has entered a tense showdown with several of the nation’s largest banks that appears likely to determine whether Chrysler survives, The New York Times’s Bill Vlasic and David E. Sanger write.

headline: Twitter Trends: Why Do Men Follow Men?
abstract: A study by researchers at Harvard Business School finds some strange gender-related patterns among Twitter users.

headline: Robin Hood Event Adjusts to Tough Times
abstract: By the gilded standards of the hedge fund world, The Robin Hood Foundation’s spring fund-raising event, which has long set the pace for charity benefits, seemed like a lean night out.

headline: Intel Fined Record $1.45 Billion in Antitrust Case
abstract: The European Commission on Wednesday fined Intel a record of about $1.45 billion (1.06 billion euros) for abusing its dominance in the market for computer chips to exclude Advanced Micro Devices, which is Intel’s only serious rival.

headline: Chrysler and Fiat Hope for Happy Relationship
abstract: When Daimler-Benz merged with Chrysler in 1998, their leaders told the world to “expect the extraordinary” from the German-American auto giant.

headline: Hail Our Alma Mater, Dear Old MDCU
abstract: Advertising agencies trying to fill all the vacant jobs in the digital realm sometimes find themselves facing a dilemma: steal people from other agencies or nurture digital talent from scratch. MDC Partners, which owns Crispin Porter & Bogusky and Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners, and dozens of other agencies, is joining with the University of Colorado at Boulder to create a school to be called Boulder Digital Works.

headline: Ratings: Sluggish Debut for ‘The Unusuals’
abstract: ABC’s new police drama “The Unusuals” made a sluggish debut in the ratings on Wednesday, earning just 6.8 million viewers in its 10 p.m. time slot, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: Hummer Buyer Lobbying Regulators, Report Says
abstract: The potential buyer of General Motors’ Hummer division will begin formal talks with Chinese regulators to seek approval for its acquisition, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Universal Express Boss Loses Appeal
abstract: Richard Altomare, the former chief executive of Universal Express, has lost his appeal to the Supreme Court. On Monday, the court turned down his request to hear his case.

headline: Hewlett-Packard and Dell Avoid Big PC Party
abstract: The world’s two largest PC makers skipped Computex. But the show is growing in influence as it morphs away from a chip and motherboard display.

headline: Scandal Casts Light on Investment Advisers
abstract: Kenneth A. Flatto paid a lot of money for expert advice about investing the pensions of municipal workers in Fairfield, Conn. Unfortunately, he says, the experts never warned him about Bernard L. Madoff.

headline: Dragging Down the World’s Economy?
abstract: How important is the economic health of the United States to that of its peer countries?

headline: U.S. Jury Finds Brokers Guilty in ‘Squawk Box’ Trial
abstract: Three former brokers and three former day traders conspired to misuse company “squawk boxes” for insider trading, a federal jury ruled on Wednesday in the second trial in the case.

headline: Sun Ready to Resume I.B.M. Talks, Report Says
abstract: Are Sun Microsystems and I.B.M. playing a game of chicken?

headline: Taking Stock of Jim Cramer’s Picks
abstract: It’s not clear if Jim Cramer will be having a rematch with Jon Stewart anytime soon — but if he does, there’s a new study the two can spar over.

headline: Q & A: Cracking Open XML Files
abstract: How to work with spreadsheet files that use the newer XML format if you’re still on the last generation of Excel.

headline: Efforts to Diversify Radio Take a Different Tack
abstract: For years, critics who complain that radio stations aimed at black and Hispanic listeners do not get their fair share of advertising revenue have made marketers the targets of their ire. Now, the spotlight is shining on the media agencies that help decide where marketers buy commercial time.

headline: Och, Doubting Stock Rally, Holds Big Cash Position
abstract: The hedge fund manager Daniel Och held about 35 percent of his $20 billion fund’s assets in cash during the first quarter because he suspects global stock markets will start falling again, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: A Silver Ooze That Could Shrink the iPod
abstract: Bill Watkins, the former chief executive of Seagate, is now at a start-up that is trying to shrink the stack of memory chips inside mobile devices.

headline: Calpers Eyes Citigroup’s TARP Assets, Report Says
abstract: Calpers, the California public pension fund, is seeking opportunities to buy assets of Citigroup and others tied to the government’s $700 billion Troubled Asset Relief Program, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Prudential to Offer $1.25 Billion in Stock
abstract: Prudential Financial, one of the largest U.S. life insurers, said it planned to sell $1.25 billion of common stock after turning down U.S. aid.

headline: Citi Won’t Sell Stakes in Chinese and Indian Banks, Report Says
abstract: Citigroup has no intention of unloading its stakes in Chinese and Indian banks, the head of Citi’s Asian operations told The Financial Times.

headline: Nurses, Parents, Paramedics Star in NBC’s New Dramas
abstract: NBC’s next season will include new dramas about parents, nurses, first responder paramedics, and life after the end of the world.

headline: The New Jitterbug J: A Comfy Cardigan of a Phone
abstract: The new Jitterbug J adds a few features, but it’s the phones optional services that really stand out.

headline: Signs of Economic Hope Lift Asian Markets
abstract: Stock markets rose across the board in the Asia-Pacific region as investors momentarily shrugged off the considerable difficulties still facing the global economic and financial system, and focused instead on fresh signs that the pace of decline is easing, The New York Times’s Bettina Wassener reported.

headline: Lewis Retains Support of Key BofA Executive
abstract: Kenneth D. Lewis, Bank of America‘s embattled chief executive, retained the backing of a top lieutenant on Friday, when Brian T. Moynihan, the head of wealth management and investment banking divisions, called Mr. Lewis the “right person” to lead the nation’s largest bank.

headline: Upfronts: ESPN Brings the Kitchen Sink
abstract: ESPN, the first cable channel to crash the broadcast upfront week, came loaded for bear. The channel came with a bear, along with a husky, cheerleaders, baseball and football players, video clips, confetti and shtick galore.

headline: AbitibiBowater Debt-Exchange Offers Expire
abstract: AbitibiBowater, a struggling maker of newsprint, announced on Wednesday that its two bond exchange offers had expired and would not be renewed, raising the specter that it could file for bankruptcy soon.

headline: Barclays Stock Drops 13.5% After Abu Dhabi Sale
abstract: Shares of Barclays, the British bank, fell sharply after Abu Dhabi sold a big part of its investment in the bank.

headline: Perella Weinberg Adds Energy Banker in London
abstract: Perella Weinberg Partners, the New York investment bank founded by some big Wall Street names three and a half years ago, has recruited a veteran energy banker to its London office.

headline: Trading Revenues Help Bank Profits Improve
abstract: The nation’s banks turned a profit in the first quarter, but the number of problem banks jumped to more than 300, the government said Wednesday.

headline: Adviser Defends U.S. Role in Aiding Automakers
abstract: By investing billions in General Motors and Chrysler, the government “saved hundreds of thousands of jobs” and gave the carmakers another chance, a leader of the U.S. auto industry task force testified.

headline: Firm Acted as Tutor in Selling Towns Risky Deals
abstract: Five years ago, Lewisburg, Tenn., a small factory town, was struggling to pay the interest on a bond for new sewers. Bob Phillips, Lewisburg’s part-time mayor and full-time pharmacist, was urged by the town’s financial adviser, an investment bank named Morgan Keegan & Company, to engage in a complex financial transaction to lower interest rates.

headline: Sunday Ratings: ABC Wins without Shaq
abstract: The Los Angeles Lakers defeated the Orlando Magic in Game 5 of the NBA Finals on Sunday, winning the championship over all and lifting ABC to another No. 1 finish in the night’s ratings.

headline: A.I.G. Chief to Fight Criticism of Employees, Report Says
abstract: American International Group‘s chief executive, Edward Liddy, will speak out against criticism of the insurer’s employees on Wednesday and talk about the company’s future plans, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Webber Talks Turkey
abstract: Mark Webber took the post race press conference as an opportunity to clarify his feelings, or backtrack, on something he had said earlier about the lack of Turkish fans at the race. It was interesting that Jenson Button, speaking in the context of the British Grand Prix, also made a reference to the lack of fans, when he said that the drivers like to perform in front of a lot of fans.

headline: Upfronts: Telemundo Talks Up Branded Entertainment
abstract: Executives of Telemundo, specializing in Spanish-language programming, gave an upbeat presentation on Monday morning to kick off the 2009-10 upfront week.

headline: G.M. Doesn’t See U.A.W. Deal Before Bond Deadline
abstract: With a week remaining before the expiration of a tender offer to its bondholders, General Motors said Tuesday that it did not expect to reach an agreement with the United Automobile Workers and others before bondholders decide.

headline: In State Pension Inquiry, a Scandal Snowballs
abstract: The inquiry into corruption at the New York State pension fund started simply enough. Alan G. Hevesi, the former comptroller, was accused of using state workers as chauffeurs for his ailing wife.

headline: Fortress Confirms Deal for Zwirn Assets
abstract: Despite recent setbacks, Fortress Investment Group may be gearing up to return to its roots as a buyer of distressed assets, The Deal writes.

headline: Attorney General Wants Financial Fraud Task Force
abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said on Thursday he was considering forming a financial fraud task force and advocated a “more comprehensive” view of the causes behind the U.S. economic crisis, Reuters reported.

headline: Morgan Stanley Chief Says No Bank Deals Imminent
abstract: Morgan Stanley is not likely to pursue a retail bank acquisition while it scrambles to complete its joint venture with Citigroup brokerage unit Smith Barney, the Morgan Stanley chief executive, John J. Mack, said.

headline: Do Young Venture Capitalists Have an Advantage?
abstract: The gods of venture capital in the 1990s might no longer be the best at picking new technologies, some limited partners say.

headline: Palm’s Pre Already Wins the Wallet Wars
abstract: The Palm Pre may not yet have Apple’s well-stocked App Store, but it does already have a leg up over the competition: A lower monthly bill.

headline: Small-Business Expansion Plans
abstract: Although one might see the increase in expansion plans since March as a good sign, the percentages over the past few months are still in very low territory compared to where they have been historically.

headline: Google Floods My Calendar With ‘Star Trek’ Geekery
abstract: Users of Google Calendar who made a note of the “Star Trek” movie’s debut got a surprise on Friday.

headline: NBA Legend’s Firm to Buy Stake in Centerplate
abstract: Basketball legend David Robinson, who last year launched his own private equity firm, has made a break for the food service company Centerplate.

headline: Records Say U.S. Pressed BofA to Cut Dividend
abstract: Should Bank of America just go ahead and change its name to Bank of the United States of America?

headline: Geithner Plan as Poker Game
abstract: Thomas Edsall explains the Geithner plan by way of analogy to a poker game.

headline: 3 Trustees of A.I.G. Are Quiet, Perhaps to a Fault
abstract: In an early sign of just how tricky corporate governance has become in the era of taxpayer bailouts, three little-known trustees with no office, no staff and almost no mission will soon be deciding questions that affect the fate of American International Group, the giant insurance company, The New York Times’s Edmund L. Andrews reported.

headline: GoldenTree Taps Goldman Executive for London Office
abstract: GoldenTree Asset Management, the credit focused hedge fund that manages $10 billion, said Tuesday it has hired Jan Kaass, a former Goldman Sachs executive, to be its head of marketing in London.

headline: In the Quad, at Least, JPMorgan Tops Goldman
abstract: For the first time in more than a decade, JPMorgan topped Goldman Sachs as the highest-ranking investment bank in Universum USA’s annual survey of college students’ top five places to work.

headline: What’s Next, ‘Daily Deal or No Deal’?
abstract: On Friday morning eBay will begin promoting a three-day campaign to stimulate interest in the Daily Deal section of its Web site (deals.ebay.com). The campaign, to run next Monday through Wednesday, is centered in Times Square and pays homage to “Let’s Make a Deal” and other venerable game shows with events in person, on signs and online.

headline: April Proves Sunny for Buyout Fundraising
abstract: April, it turns out, has not been the cruelest month — at least not for private equity firms seeking to raise funds.

headline: Visual Diary: The Viewer
abstract: Never in history have we been surrounded by more imagery and photography than today. But paradoxically we also seem to live in increasingly text-driven societies.

headline: Newspapers Begin to Use Zillow
abstract: Zillow.com, a real estate Web site, is partnering with 180 local newspapers to deliver hyper-local home listings and market information.

headline: Westpac Reports Weaker Earnings
abstract: Westpac Banking, Australia’s second-largest bank, reported weaker half-year earnings on Wednesday as bad-debt charges tripled, and it joined its rivals in cutting dividends and warning of worse to come.

headline: F1 Talks Fail – But Continue
abstract: So as Formula One prepares for its most commercially important race of the year, the Monaco Grand Prix next week, it has left an odor of financial breakdown in the air. Funny enough, it’s the FIA that wants teams to spend less in these recessionary times while certain teams actually want to spend more!

headline: Intelius Said to Acquire Search Engine Company
abstract: Intelius, a company that performs background checks on people, has acquired Spock, a people search engine, for an undisclosed amount, VentureBeat reported.

headline: TLC President Talks About ‘Jon & Kate’
abstract: Jon and Kate Gosselin are separating, but the show will still be named “Jon & Kate Plus 8.” Eileen O’Neill, the president of TLC, says there are no plans to change the title.

headline: KERS Revisted
abstract: The Kinetic Energy Recovery System, or KERS, continues to come up as a topic in almost every press conference and press scrum this year even as we move into the fourth race. And it’s still not sorted out.

headline: Four Big Banks Drop Appeal in Milan Case
abstract: UBS, Deutsche Bank, JPMorgan Chase and Depfa Bank have dropped an appeal against the seizure of 345 million euros ($482 million) of their assets amid an investigation of fraud involving derivatives sold to the city of Milan.

headline: Arriving in America – The Other Side of This War
abstract: I am now on the other side of this war. The less violent side.

headline: G.M. Plans New Bond-Exchange Offer
abstract: General Motors is working on a new debt-exchange plan for its bondholders, one that would likely offer only equity instead of cash or new debt, a person briefed on the proposal told DealBook on Thursday.

headline: Shamrock Said to Be in Talks for Motorola Unit
abstract: Shamrock Holdings, an investment arm of the Walt Disney Company, is said to be in talks with Motorola about buying MIRS Communications, an Israeli cellular operator.

headline: JPMorgan Hires Senior Merrill Deal Maker
abstract: JPMorgan Chase said it hired a senior Merrill Lynch deal-maker as its new vice chairman of mergers and acquisitions, the latest in a reshuffling of investment banking ranks.

headline: Adobe Wants to Reshape Online Video
abstract: Adobe is developing Adobe Story, a new software tool that could give viewers the power to search for content within online videos.

headline: Change in Bank Rules Lifts Stocks
abstract: Hopes that the worst days of the financial crisis are retreating lifted stock markets on Thursday after government leaders pledged huge new financial rescues and a regulatory group moved to rewrite financial regulations and accounting rules.

headline: Justices Reject Ruling on Retrial of Enron Executive
abstract: The Supreme Court has sided with a former Enron executive in a ruling that makes it unlikely he will be tried a second time on charges related to financial fraud.

headline: Disney Gets In on the Netbook Craze
abstract: Disney’s new netbook offers built-in safety measures for a kid’s Web activity, not to mention an exterior design that would stand out in a conference room.

headline: Debtholders vs. U.S. Over Chrysler Deal
abstract: The Obama administration has entered a tense showdown with several of the nation’s largest banks that appears likely to determine whether Chrysler survives, The New York Times’s Bill Vlasic and David E. Sanger write.

headline: Twitter Trends: Why Do Men Follow Men?
abstract: A study by researchers at Harvard Business School finds some strange gender-related patterns among Twitter users.

headline: Robin Hood Event Adjusts to Tough Times
abstract: By the gilded standards of the hedge fund world, The Robin Hood Foundation’s spring fund-raising event, which has long set the pace for charity benefits, seemed like a lean night out.

headline: Intel Fined Record $1.45 Billion in Antitrust Case
abstract: The European Commission on Wednesday fined Intel a record of about $1.45 billion (1.06 billion euros) for abusing its dominance in the market for computer chips to exclude Advanced Micro Devices, which is Intel’s only serious rival.

headline: Chrysler and Fiat Hope for Happy Relationship
abstract: When Daimler-Benz merged with Chrysler in 1998, their leaders told the world to “expect the extraordinary” from the German-American auto giant.

headline: Hail Our Alma Mater, Dear Old MDCU
abstract: Advertising agencies trying to fill all the vacant jobs in the digital realm sometimes find themselves facing a dilemma: steal people from other agencies or nurture digital talent from scratch. MDC Partners, which owns Crispin Porter & Bogusky and Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners, and dozens of other agencies, is joining with the University of Colorado at Boulder to create a school to be called Boulder Digital Works.

headline: Ratings: Sluggish Debut for ‘The Unusuals’
abstract: ABC’s new police drama “The Unusuals” made a sluggish debut in the ratings on Wednesday, earning just 6.8 million viewers in its 10 p.m. time slot, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: Hummer Buyer Lobbying Regulators, Report Says
abstract: The potential buyer of General Motors’ Hummer division will begin formal talks with Chinese regulators to seek approval for its acquisition, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Universal Express Boss Loses Appeal
abstract: Richard Altomare, the former chief executive of Universal Express, has lost his appeal to the Supreme Court. On Monday, the court turned down his request to hear his case.

headline: Actelis Said to Nab Another $4.7 Million
abstract: Actelis Networks, a maker of equipment that lets ethernet run over copper wires, has added a further $4.7 million to $15 million sixth round of funding, VentureWire reported. The additional financing would bring the total Actelis has raised since its inception to $140 million.

headline: Health Care Priorities Series
abstract: On Tuesday, we ran a series of posts from experts and stakeholders about what the priorities should be for reforming America’s health care system. Here are links to all of them.

headline: GMAC, Among the Weakest, Seems in Line for a Bailout
abstract: It looks as if one more bank needs a bailout. And, four months ago, this bank was not even a bank.

headline: EMC Tops NetApp’s Bid for Data Domain
abstract: EMC is offering $30 a share in cash, or about $1.8 billion, to acquire Data Domain, a data backup company, in a bid that represents a 20 percent premium over a rival offer from NetApp.

headline: OpenTable Lifts I.P.O. Price Range
abstract: OpenTable is looking increasingly confident as it prepares to break a nine-month drought in venture-backed initial public offerings.

headline: Rally May Be Cause for Hope, or a Blip
abstract: Is it safe to exhale yet?

headline: Thursday Ratings: Crime Repeats Beat Spelling Bee
abstract: Crime show repeats on CBS drew the most viewers on network television on Thursday while another two-hour audition round of “So You Think You Can Dance” helped Fox rank second over all.

headline: Cuomo Ends Inquiry Into Auction-Rate Debt
abstract: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York said Wednesday that six major banks had satisfied the terms of settlements over their sale of auction-rate debt that became illiquid despite being marketed as being as safe as cash.

headline: U.A.W. Likely to Get Less Than 39% of G.M.
abstract: Contrary to popular belief, the United Auto Workers union will likely get “substantially less” than 39 percent of General Motors as part of a deal between the two parties, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook.

headline: Prosecutors Again Delay Indicting Madoff Accountant
abstract: Prosecutors have delayed for a third time the indictment of David G. Friehling, the accountant who provided auditing services to Bernard L. Madoff’s investment advisory business, in a sign he may be cooperating with investigators.

headline: With New Chief, Is a Deal in Huffington’s Future?
abstract: Now that The Huffington Post has tapped Softbank Capital‘s managing partner and investor, Eric Hippeau, as its new chief executive, is a little deal-making on the horizon?

headline: More on Verizon Wireless’ MiFi
abstract: Continued discussion about Verizon Wireless’ MiFi portable Wi-Fi hotspot.

headline: Buyout Fees: An Endangered Species
abstract: So far this year, banks have collected a combined $1 billion worldwide from their work for private equity firms, according to data from Delalogic. That’s roughly the same amount that they made in the first eight weeks of 2008.

headline: Upfronts: Fox Schedules Wanda Sykes For Fall
abstract: Wanda Skyes’ late-night talk show, tentatively titled — what else? — “The Wanda Sykes Show,” is scheduled to premiere on Saturday, Nov. 7, Fox said on Monday.

headline: MediaNews Reaches Deal to Defer Debt Payments
abstract: MediaNews, the debt-burdened newspaper company, has struck an accord with its lenders and its bondholders in which it will forgo making a principal payment on its debt, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Crispin Porter Stamps Its Passport
abstract: One of the hottest American agencies, Crispin Porter & Bogusky — known for its rule-breaking, risk-taking work for advertisers like Burger King, Microsoft, Old Navy and Volkswagen — is expanding significantly in Europe.

headline: When Credit Ratings Do a Vanishing Act
abstract: The big credit rating agencies are shrinking their coverage at an increasing pace, because of bankruptcies, defaults and issuers that don’t want to pay for weak ratings.

headline: Lloyds Set to Repay $4 Billion to Britain
abstract: Lloyds Banking Group, the biggest mortgage lender in Britain, said it would repay the government about $4.1 billion after selling shares to investors.

headline: 11 States Join U.S. in A.I.G. Bonus Inquiry
abstract: Eleven states that are looking into employee bonuses paid by A.I.G. plan to join federal investigators in pursuing the matter rather than press the case themselves.

headline: Putin Says Magna Asked GAZ to Make Opel Bid
abstract: The Canadian-Austrian auto-parts maker, Magna, has asked the Russian carmaker GAZ, to make a bid for a stake in General Motors‘ German carmaker unit, Opel, Russia’s prime minister, Vladimir Putin, has said, according to Reuters.

headline: Layoffs Aren’t the Main Problem
abstract: Companies are not laying off workers at a much more rapid pace than in 2001. But companies are adding jobs far, far more slowly.

headline: Garmin GPS Device Adds a Built-In Camera
abstract: Garmin’s new Oregon 550 GPS device enables built-in geotagging with a 3.2-megapixel digital camera.

headline: Chrysler’s Lenders Prepare a Counteroffer
abstract: Even as the Treasury Department directs Chrysler to prepare a bankruptcy filing for as soon as next week, a committee representing the carmaker’s senior lenders is drawing up another counteroffer on how to reduce the company’s roughly $7 billion in debt, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Thursday.

headline: BG Acquires Gas Assets From Exco of Texas
abstract: The Globe and Mail reported that BG Group said it would pay Dallas-based Exco Resources $1.3 billion for an interest in shale gas resources, as oil and gas firms continue to snap up assets.

headline: BofA to Name Vice Chairman of Investment Banking
abstract: Bank of America appears set to name the head of its Merrill Lynch Middle Eastern banking business, Fares Noujaim, to be its vice chairman of global corporate and investment banking, according to people familiar with the bank’s plans.

headline: Going Back in Time: Progress, or Lack Thereof, Around the Country
abstract: On average, America experienced great progress in human well-being in the last half century. But these averages hide a world of variation, as well as just how much certain groups have been left behind in that path towards progress. Going from Manhattan’s East Side to the South Bronx, for example, is a trip back in time in terms of human development, two researchers write.

headline: The Nation’s C.I.O.: Government Needs a Dashboard
abstract: Vivek Kundra, the nation’s new chief information officer, is about to introduce a new dashboard to see which of the 800 government technology projects are going off track.

headline: O’Reilly Marks 100 Months at No. 1
abstract: Bill O’Reilly is marking an anniversary this week.

headline: The Sebastian Vettel Show
abstract: Sebastian Vettel’s second career pole position, scored during qualifying for the Chinese Grand Prix outside Shanghai today, was an even more impressive show than was his first pole at the Italian Grand Prix in Monza last September. The young German driver waited until the final minutes of the second qualifying round before going onto the track and setting the fastest time of that session on a single flying lap. He then did exactly the same thing in the third qualifying session – he waited until the very last minute, took to the track and did a single flying lap (excluding the out lap, of course) and took the pole position.

headline: A Crucial Hearing in the Creation of a New G.M.
abstract: General Motors went to bankruptcy court Tuesday to begin the process of selling its best assets to a government-backed company that would become the linchpin of its turnaround plan.

headline: A Not-So-Happy Birthday for Madoff
abstract: Bernard L. Madoff observed his 71st birthday behind bars in Lower Manhattan on Wednesday, with no party and little to celebrate as he awaits what is likely to be a lifetime sentence after pleading guilty to running an enormous Ponzi scheme.

headline: Immelt Opposes Splitting Off GE Capital
abstract: General Electric opposes any regulation that would force it to split off its hefty finance business, its chief executive said in a memo to employees.

headline: ‘Jon & Kate’ Continues to Attract Big Audiences
abstract: The new season of “Jon & Kate Plus 8″ continues to attract a big audience after its splashy debut last week.

headline: An Offer They Couldn’t Refuse

headline: In Russia,  TV News Matters
abstract: It does in Russia, according to a new study that looked at whether access to an independent TV news station affected voting decisions.

headline: Visual Diary: The Wounded Militiaman
abstract: This war is not over yet.

headline: Small Batch Lands Fresh Round
abstract: Small Batch, which designs and develops web applications, has landed a round funding led by True Ventures and including some high-profile individual investors.

headline: K.K.R. and Fidelity Reach I.P.O. Partnership

abstract: U.S. Embassy Deputy Chief of Mission Patricia A. Butenis talks agriculture with women from Anbar Province.

headline: Correction

The picture showed a Somali man working as a bodyguard during the congressman’s visit  not Andrea Phillips, the wife of the ship captain, who was shown in a photograph in earlier editions.

headline: Britain: Lloyds Plans More Cuts

Lloyds said it planned to create 70 posts in risk management, mostly in Edinburgh. The company has pledged to lower costs after the acquisition of HBOS in January created a bank with more than 3,000 branches and a 28 percent share of Britain’s mortgage market. Lloyds, now 43 percent government-owned, is seeking to save more than £1.5 billion ($2.5 billion) by 2011.
