headline: Disney Gets In on the Netbook Craze
abstract: Disney’s new netbook offers built-in safety measures for a kid’s Web activity, not to mention an exterior design that would stand out in a conference room.

headline: Debtholders vs. U.S. Over Chrysler Deal
abstract: The Obama administration has entered a tense showdown with several of the nation’s largest banks that appears likely to determine whether Chrysler survives, The New York Times’s Bill Vlasic and David E. Sanger write.

headline: Twitter Trends: Why Do Men Follow Men?
abstract: A study by researchers at Harvard Business School finds some strange gender-related patterns among Twitter users.

headline: Robin Hood Event Adjusts to Tough Times
abstract: By the gilded standards of the hedge fund world, The Robin Hood Foundation’s spring fund-raising event, which has long set the pace for charity benefits, seemed like a lean night out.

headline: Intel Fined Record $1.45 Billion in Antitrust Case
abstract: The European Commission on Wednesday fined Intel a record of about $1.45 billion (1.06 billion euros) for abusing its dominance in the market for computer chips to exclude Advanced Micro Devices, which is Intel’s only serious rival.

headline: Chrysler and Fiat Hope for Happy Relationship
abstract: When Daimler-Benz merged with Chrysler in 1998, their leaders told the world to “expect the extraordinary” from the German-American auto giant.

headline: Hail Our Alma Mater, Dear Old MDCU
abstract: Advertising agencies trying to fill all the vacant jobs in the digital realm sometimes find themselves facing a dilemma: steal people from other agencies or nurture digital talent from scratch. MDC Partners, which owns Crispin Porter & Bogusky and Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners, and dozens of other agencies, is joining with the University of Colorado at Boulder to create a school to be called Boulder Digital Works.

headline: Ratings: Sluggish Debut for ‘The Unusuals’
abstract: ABC’s new police drama “The Unusuals” made a sluggish debut in the ratings on Wednesday, earning just 6.8 million viewers in its 10 p.m. time slot, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: Hummer Buyer Lobbying Regulators, Report Says
abstract: The potential buyer of General Motors’ Hummer division will begin formal talks with Chinese regulators to seek approval for its acquisition, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Universal Express Boss Loses Appeal
abstract: Richard Altomare, the former chief executive of Universal Express, has lost his appeal to the Supreme Court. On Monday, the court turned down his request to hear his case.

headline: Visual Diary: A Slide Revisited
abstract: A boy on a slide may be a good metaphor for the mood in Iraq.

headline: Google Chief Chats Up Twitter
abstract: Responding to questions from analysts about rumors that Google has had conversations about a possible partnership with Twitter, GigaOm notes that Google’s chief executive, Eric E. Schmidt, gave the microblogging service a nice plug:

headline: Losses in Good-Will Values Dog Bank Deals
abstract: When times were flush, businesses bought up rivals and absorbed smaller companies to grow as big as possible as fast as possible. But now, those purchases are starting to look a lot like housing bought at the peak of the bubble — overpriced and losing value fast, The New York Times’s Jack Healy says.

headline: The Pepsi Challenge: How to Structure a Deal
abstract: PepsiCo announced earlier this week that it offered a combined $6 billion to reacquire its two bottling units, but the hard part of the deals may still lie ahead. In addition to the question of price — many analysts and investors think Pepsi will need to raise its bids — there is the issue of how Pepsi will structure the transactions, as either traditional “forward” mergers or reverse triangular mergers.

headline: Rallies for Shares and Oil Begin to Falter
abstract: Pessimism filtered back into the financial markets Wednesday, tripping rallies in shares and oil, after the Federal Reserve chairman warned the U.S. economy would probably recover slowly.

headline: New Software, New iPhone, New Steve? Live-Blogging the Apple Extravaganza
abstract: Up-to-the-minute news and analysis from Apple’s Worldwide Developers Conference in San Francisco.

headline: Takeover of Belgian Bank Sparks Anger at Meeting
abstract: Having failed in court to block a takeover by a big French bank, angry shareholders at Fortis, once Belgium’s biggest bank, tried to vote with their feet on Tuesday — or, more precisely, their shoes.

headline: Rio Tinto Considers Ending China Deal
abstract: China’s proposed $19.5 billion investment in Rio Tinto, the Australian mining giant, could be scrapped this week, ending this country’s bid to gain a larger stake in one of the world’s biggest resource companies.

headline: G.M. Said to Be Close to Sale of Saab
abstract: General Motors is close to selling Saab to Koenigsegg, a Swedish maker of high-end sports cars, a person close to the negotiations said.

headline: Wells Fargo Posts $3 Billion in 1st-Quarter Profit
abstract: Wells Fargo on Wednesday delivered what it said it would: a $3 billion first-quarter profit.

headline: NEC Electronics and Renesas to Merge Chip Businesses
abstract: NEC Electronics and Renesas Technology said Monday they have agreed to merge their operations and form the world’s third-largest semiconductor maker.

headline: A Service to Prove You Are Really You
abstract: Equifax wants to tap into an emerging identity standard to help people prove they really are who they say they are

headline: Video Games Aren’t Recession-Proof
abstract: May is the first month that industry sales have dipped below $1 billion since August 2007. The Wii, Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 couldn’t protect the industry from the recession.

headline: Judge Sets Auction Date for Dreier’s Hamptons Homes
abstract: Two luxury Hamptons properties belonging to Marc S. Dreier, the prominent Manhattan lawyer who pleaded guilty this month to criminal fraud charges, will be auctioned June 17 in the Hamptons.

headline: Not Yet Worse Than 1982
abstract: Job losses have been larger than they were in the early 1980s recession. But the job market still isn’t in as bad shape as it was then.

headline: Tip of the Week: Adobe Reader’s ‘Read Aloud’ Feature
abstract: Synthetic-voice technology makes PDF files come alive (sorta) in Adobe’s new PDF-viewing software.

headline: More on How Other Countries Do Health Care
abstract: Earlier today, Uwe E. Reinhardt wrote about ways to revamp the American health care system, focusing on the German model.

headline: Live Blogging Timothy Geithner on Capitol Hill
abstract: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner is heading to Congress on Thursday to discuss the Obama administration’s plan to overhaul financial regulations. DealBook plans to live-blog his testimony, which is scheduled to begin at 9:30 a.m.

headline: Upfronts: CBS Lineup Includes NBC Castoff and NCIS Spinoff
abstract: CBS will introduce one new sitcom to Monday nightand add two dramas on Tuesday night in the fall.

headline: About 10 U.S. Stress Test Banks to Need More Capital
abstract: About 10 of the 19 largest U.S. banks being stress tested will be instructed by regulators to raise more capital, Reuters reported, citing a source familiar with official talks.

headline: F.D.I.C. Charges Banks New Fee to Replenish Fund
abstract: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation voted on Friday to levy an emergency fee on the nation’s banks in an effort to replenish the insurance fund amid the fastest pace of bank failures since 1994.

headline: Health Reform Without a Public Plan: The German Model
abstract: Compromise on President Obama’s health care plan would not necessarily end meaningful reform, if the systems of the Netherlands, Germany and Switzerland are any guide, an economist writes.

headline: Qatar Still Considering a Stake in Porsche
abstract: Qatar is still considering taking a stake in debt-laden Porsche, or other German auto companies, after the carmaker scaled down a bid for Volkswagen, the Gulf emirate’s prime minister said Saturday.

headline: Harbinger Said to Conduct Review of Salton
abstract: Harbinger Capital Partners is up to something with its home-appliance business Salton, The New York Post reported, though its sources differed as to whether it was considering a sale or a refinancing.

headline: Google Revs Up Some New Search Features
abstract: Google unveils enhancements to its search service, as well as new experimental features that attempt to make sense of data available on the Web.

headline: More Jackson Specials to Be Seen Friday
abstract: Interest in the death of Michael Jackson continued to dominate many television channels Friday, with two networks planning a second night of news specials and the cable news networks devoting a substantial number of hours to continuing coverage of the star’s life and career.

headline: How Lehman Brothers Got Its Real Estate Fix
abstract: Back when he was a major Wall Street deal maker, Mark A. Walsh, the former head of the global real estate group at Lehman Brothers, had a running joke with Carmine Visone, one of his managing directors. Mr. Visone, 10 years older than his boss, would lecture Mr. Walsh about the importance of fundamentals: land values, construction cost and rents.

headline: Universal Health Care, via Cost Cutting
abstract: A health economist argues that making the medical system more efficient can indeed pay for universal insurance.

headline: Taiwan Goes Upmarket With Software Shops
abstract: Long a giant in hardware, Taiwan is readying the next. Companies are developing software that enhances the electronics they are already building.

headline: The G Stands for Gamer
abstract: Will the iPhone 3G S solidify Apple as a new contender in the video-gaming industry?
